edition.printer: Roger Daniel, John Hayes, Alice Warren

scene.scenelocation: London. A room in Matthew Flowerdale’s house.

stagedir.dir: Enter Old Flowerdale and his brother.

speech.speaker: OLD. FLOW.
speech.line: Brother, from Venice, being thus disguised,
I come to prove the humors of my son:
How hath he borne himself since my departure,
I leaving you his patron and his guide?

speech.speaker: UNCLE.
speech.line: I’faith, brother, so as you will grieve to hear,
And I almost ashamed to report it.

speech.speaker: OLD. FLOW.
speech.line: Why, how is’t, brother? What doth he spend beyond the allowance I left him?

speech.speaker: UNCLE.
speech.line: How! Beyond that and far more: why, your exhibition is nothing. He hath spent that, and since hath borrowed, protested with oaths, alleged kindred to wring money from me, by the love I bore his father, by the fortunes might fall upon himself, to furnish his wants. That done, I have had since his bond, his friend, and friend’s bond although I know that he spends is yours, yet it grieves me to see the unbridled wildness that reigns over him.

speech.speaker: OLD. FLOW.
speech.line: Brother, what is the manner of his life? How is the name of his offenses? If they do not relish altogether of damnation, his youth may privilege his wantonness: I myself ran an unbridled course till thirty, nay almost till forty; well, you see how I am: for vice once looked into with the eyes of discretion, and well balanced with the weights of reason, the course past seems so abominable that the landlord of himself, which is the heart of his body, will rather entomb himself in the earth, or seek a new tenant to remain in him, which once settled, how much better are they that in their youth have known all these vices and left it, than those that knew little and in their age runs into it? Believe me, brother, they that die most virtuous hath in their youth lived most vicious, and none knows the danger of the fire more than he that falls into it. But say, how is the course of his life? Letâ€™s hear his particulars.

speech.speaker: UNCLE.
speech.line: Why, I’ll tell you, brother. He is a continual swearer, and a breaker of his oaths, which is bad.

speech.speaker: OLD. FLOW.
speech.line: I grant indeed to swear is bad, but not keeping those oaths is better, for who will set by a bad thing? Nay, by my faith, I hold this rather a virtue than a vice. Well, I pray, proceed.

speech.speaker: UNCLE.
speech.line: He is a mighty brawler and comes commonly by the worst.

speech.speaker: OLD. FLOW.
speech.line: By my faith, this is none of the worst neither, for if he brawl and be beaten for it, it will in time make him shun it: for what brings man or child more to virtue than correction? What reigns over him else?

speech.speaker: UNCLE.
speech.line: He is a great drinker, and one that will forget himself.

speech.speaker: OLD. FLOW.
speech.line: O, best of all, vice should be forgotten:
Let him drink on, so he drink not churches.
Nay, an this be the worst, I hold it rather a happiness in him
Than any iniquity. Hath he any more attendants?

speech.speaker: UNCLE.
speech.line: Brother, he is one that will borrow of any man.

speech.speaker: OLD. FLOW.
speech.line: Why, you see, so doth the sea: it borrows of all the small currents in the world to increase himself.

speech.speaker: UNCLE.
speech.line: Ay, but the sea pays it again, and so will never your son.

speech.speaker: OLD. FLOW.
speech.line: No more would the sea neither, if it were as dry as my son.

speech.speaker: UNCLE.
speech.line: Then, brother, I see you rather like these vices in your son than any way condemn them.

speech.speaker: OLD. FLOW.
speech.line: Nay, mistake me not, brother, for though I slur them over now,
As things slight and nothing, his crimes being in the bud,
It would gall my heart they should ever reign in him.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: Ho! Who’s within? Ho!

speech.speaker: UNCLE.
speech.line: That’s your son: he is come to borrow more money.

speech.speaker: OLD. FLOW.
speech.line: For God’s sake, give it out I am dead, see how he’ll take it;
Say I have brought you news from his father.
I have here drawn a formal will, as it were
From myself, which I’ll deliver him.

speech.speaker: UNCLE.
speech.line: Go to, brother, no more: I will.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: Uncle, where are you, uncle?

speech.speaker: UNCLE.
speech.line: Let my cousin in there.

speech.speaker: OLD. FLOW.
speech.line: I am a sailor come from Venice and my name is Christopher.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: By the Lord, in truth, uncle.

speech.speaker: UNCLE.
speech.line: ‘In truth’ would ha’ served, cousin, without the ‘Lord’.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: By your leave, uncle, the Lord is the Lord of truth.
A couple of rascals at the gate set upon me for my purse.

speech.speaker: UNCLE.
speech.line: You never come but you bring a brawl in your mouth.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: By my truth, uncle, you must needs lend me ten pound.

speech.speaker: UNCLE.
speech.line: Give my cousin some small beer here.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: Nay, look you, you turn it to a jest now.
By this light, I should ride to Croydon Fair
To meet Sir Lancelot Spurcock.
I should have his daughter Luce, and for scurvy ten pound,
A man shall lose nine hundred threescore and odd pounds,
And a daily friend beside, by this hand,
Uncle, ’tis true.

speech.speaker: UNCLE.
speech.line: Why, anything is true, for aught I know.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: To see now: why, you shall have my bond, uncle, or Tom White’s, James Brock’s, or Nick Hall’s — as good rapier and dagger men as any be in England. Let’s be damned if we do not pay you: the worst of us all will not damn ourselves for ten pound. A pox of ten pound!

speech.speaker: UNCLE.
speech.line: Cousin, this is not the first time I have believed you.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: Why, trust me now, you know not what may fall.
If one thing were but true, I would not greatly care,
I should not need ten pound, but when a man
Cannot be believed, there’s it.

speech.speaker: UNCLE.
speech.line: Why, what is it, cousin?

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: Marry, this, uncle. Can you tell me if the Katernhugh be come home or no?

speech.speaker: UNCLE.
speech.line: Ay, marry, is’t.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: By God, I thank you for that news. What, is’t in the Pool, can you tell?

speech.speaker: UNCLE.
speech.line: It is. What of that?

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: What? Why then I have six pieces of velvet sent me.
I’ll give you a piece, uncle, for thus said the letter:
‘A piece of ash-color, a three-piled black,
A color-de-roy, a crimson, a sad green,
And a purple’: yes, i’faith.

speech.speaker: UNCLE.
speech.line: From whom should you receive this?

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: From who? Why, from my father! With commendations to you, uncle, and thus he writes: ‘I know’, saith he, ‘thou hast much troubled thy kind uncle whom, God willing, at my return, I will see amply satisfied.’ ‘Amply’, I remember, was the very word, so God help me.

speech.speaker: UNCLE.
speech.line: Have you the letter here?

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: Yes, I have the letter here: here is the letter: no, yes, no! Let me see, what breeches wore I o’Saturday? Let me see, o’Tuesday my calamanco, o’Wednesday my peach-color satin, o’Thursday my velour, o’Friday my calamanco again, o’Saturday, let me see, o’Saturday — for in those breeches I wore o’Saturday is the letter: O, my riding breeches, uncle, those that you thought had been velvet. In those very breeches is the letter.

speech.speaker: UNCLE.
speech.line: When should it be dated?

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: Marry, duodecimo tertios septembris, no, no, tredecimo tertio octobris. Ay, octobris, so it is.

speech.speaker: UNCLE.
speech.line: Duodecimo tertios octobris: and here receive I a letter that your father died in June. How say you, Kester?

speech.speaker: OLD. FLOW.
speech.line: Yes, truly, sir, your father is dead: these hands of mine holp to wind him.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: Dead?

speech.speaker: OLD. FLOW.
speech.line: Ay, sir, dead.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: ’Sblood, how should my father come dead?

speech.speaker: OLD. FLOW.
speech.line: I’faith, sir, according to the old proverb:
‘The child was born and cried,
Became man, after, fell sick, and died.’

speech.speaker: UNCLE.
speech.line: Nay, cousin, do not take it so heavily.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: Nay, I cannot weep you extempore. Marry, some two or three days hence, I shall weep without any stintance. But I hope he died in good memory.

speech.speaker: OLD. FLOW.
speech.line: Very well, sir, and set down everything in good order.
And the Katherine and Hugh you talked of, I came over in,
And I saw all the bills of lading, and the velvet
That you talked of, there is no such aboard.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: By God, I assure you, then there is knavery abroad.

speech.speaker: OLD. FLOW.
speech.line: I’ll be sworn of that: there’s knavery abroad,
Although there were never a piece of velvet in Venice.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: I hope he died in good estate.

speech.speaker: OLD. FLOW.
speech.line: To the report of the world he did, and made his will,
Of which I am an unworthy bearer.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: His will? Have you his will?

speech.speaker: OLD. FLOW.
speech.line: Yes, sir, and in the presence of your uncle,
I was willed to deliver it.

speech.speaker: UNCLE.
speech.line: I hope, cousin, now God hath blessed you with wealth, you will not be unmindful of me.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: I’ll do reason, uncle: yet, i’faith, I take the denial of this ten pound very hardly.

speech.speaker: UNCLE.
speech.line: Nay, I denied you not.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: By God, you denied me directly.

speech.speaker: UNCLE.
speech.line: I’ll be judged by this good fellow.

speech.speaker: OLD. FLOW.
speech.line: Not directly, sir.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: Why, he said he would lend me none, and that had wont to be a direct denial, if the old phrase hold. Well, uncle, come, we’ll fall to the legacies. ‘In the name of God, Amen. Item: I bequeath to my brother Flowerdale three

hundred pounds to pay such trivial debts as I owe in London. Item: to my son, Mat Flowerdale, I bequeath two bale of false dice, videlicet, high men and low men, fulhams, stop cater-treys, and other bones of function.’ ’Sblood, what doth he mean by this?

speech.speaker: UNCLE.
speech.line: Proceed, cousin.

speech.speaker: FLOW.

line.recite: ‘These precepts I leave him. Let him borrow of his oath,
For of his word nobody will trust him.
Let him by no means marry an honest woman,
For the other will keep herself.
Let him steal as much as he can, that a guilty conscience
May bring him to his destinate repentance.’

speech.line: I think he means hanging. An this were his last will and testament, the devil stood laughing at his bed’s feet while he made it. ’Sblood, what, doth he think to fob off his posterity with paradoxes?

speech.speaker: OLD. FLOW.
speech.line: This he made, sir, with his own hands.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: Ay, well. Nay, come, good uncle, let me have this ten pound. Imagine you have lost it, or robbed of it, or misreckoned yourself so much — any way to make it come easily off, good uncle.

speech.speaker: UNCLE.
speech.line: Not a penny.

speech.speaker: OLD. FLOW.
speech.line: I’faith, lend it him, sir. I myself have an estate in the city worth twenty pound: all that I’ll engage for him: he saith it concerns him in a marriage.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: Ay, marry, doth it: this is a fellow of some sense, this. Come, good uncle.

speech.speaker: UNCLE.
speech.line: Will you give your word for it, Kester?

speech.speaker: OLD. FLOW.
speech.line: I will, sir, willingly.

speech.speaker: UNCLE.
speech.line: Well, cousin, come to me some hour hence, you shall have it ready.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: Shall I not fail?

speech.speaker: UNCLE.
speech.line: You shall not: come, or send.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: Nay, I’ll come myself.

speech.speaker: OLD. FLOW.
speech.line: By my troth, would I were your worship’s man.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: What, wouldst thou serve?

speech.speaker: OLD. FLOW.
speech.line: Very willingly, sir.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: Why, I’ll tell thee what thou shalt do. Thou saith thou hast twenty pound: go into Birchin Lane, put thyself into clothes; thou shalt ride with me to Croydon Fair.

speech.speaker: OLD. FLOW.
speech.line: I thank you, sir. I will attend you.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: Well, uncle, you will not fail me an hour hence?

speech.speaker: UNCLE.
speech.line: I will not, cousin.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: What’s thy name — Kester?

speech.speaker: OLD. FLOW.
speech.line: Ay, sir.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: Well, provide thyself. Uncle, farewell till anon.

speech.speaker: UNCLE.
speech.line: Brother, how do you like your son?

speech.speaker: OLD. FLOW.
speech.line: I’faith, brother, like a mad unbridled colt,
Or as a hawk, that never stooped to lure:
The one must be tamed with an iron bit,
The other must be watched, or still she is wild —
Such is my son. Awhile let him be so,
For counsel still is folly’s deadly foe.
I’ll serve his youth, for youth must have his course,
For being restrained, it makes him ten times worse.
His pride, his riot, all that may be named,
Time may recall, and all his madness tamed.

scene.scenelocation: The high street in Croydon Fair. An inn with an open drinking booth before it.

stagedir.dir: Enter Sir Lancelot, Master Weathercock, Daffodil, Artichoke, Luce, and Frances.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Sirrah Artichoke, get you home before,
And, as you proved yourself a calf in buying,
Drive home your fellow calves that you have bought.

speech.speaker: ART.
speech.line: Yes, forsooth. Shall not my fellow Daffodil go along with me?

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: No, sir, no: I must have one to wait on me.

speech.speaker: ART.
speech.line: Daffodil, farewell, good fellow Daffodil.
You may see, mistress, I am set up by the halves:
Instead of waiting on you, I am sent to drive home calves.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: I’faith, Franck, I must turn away this Daffodil,
He’s grown a very foolish, saucy fellow.

speech.speaker: FRAN.
speech.line: Indeed la, father, he was so since I had him:
Before, he was wise enough for a foolish serving-man.

speech.speaker: WEATH.
speech.line: But what say you to me, Sir Lancelot?

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: O, about my daughters, well, I will go forward,
Here’s two of them, God save them, but the third,
O, she’s a stranger in her course of life;
She hath refused you, Master Weathercock.

speech.speaker: WEATH.
speech.line: Ay, by the rood, Sir Lancelot, that she hath,
But had she tried me, she should ha’ found a man of me indeed.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Nay, be not angry, sir, at her denial:
She hath refused seven of the worshipfullest,
And worthiest, housekeepers this day in Kent:
Indeed, she will not marry, I suppose.

speech.speaker: WEATH.
speech.line: The more fool she!

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: What, is it folly to love charity?

speech.speaker: WEATH.
speech.line: No, mistake me not, Sir Lancelot,
But ’tis an old proverb, and you know it well.
That women, dying maids, lead apes in hell.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: That’s a foolish proverb and a false.

speech.speaker: WEATH.
speech.line: By the mass, I think it be, and therefore let it go.
But who shall marry with Mistress Frances?

speech.speaker: FRAN.
speech.line: By my troth, they are talking of marrying me, sister.

speech.speaker: LUCE.
speech.line: Peace, let them talk:
Fools may have leave to prattle as they walk.

speech.speaker: DAFF.
speech.line: Sentences still, sweet mistress?
You have a wit, and it were your arbalester.

speech.speaker: LUCE.
speech.line: I’faith, and thy tongue trips trenchmore.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: No, of my knighthood, not a suitor yet:
Alas, God help her, silly girl, a fool, a very fool:
But there’s the other black-brows, a shrewd girl.
She hath wit at will and suitors two or three:
Sir Arthur Greenshield one, a gallant knight,
A valiant soldier, but his power but poor.
Then there’s young Oliver, the Devonshire lad,
A wary fellow, marry, full of wit,
And rich, by the rood: but there’s a third all air,
Light as a feather, changing as the wind: young Flowerdale.

speech.speaker: WEATH.
speech.line: O, he, sir, he’s a desperate Dick indeed.
Bar him your house!

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Fie, not so: he’s of good parentage.

speech.speaker: WEATH.
speech.line: By my fay, and so he is, and a proper man.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Ay, proper enough, had he good qualities.

speech.speaker: WEATH.
speech.line: Ay, marry, there’s the point, Sir Lancelot,
For there’s an old saying:
“Be he rich, or be he poor,
Be he high, or be he low,
Be he born in barn, or hall,
’Tis manners makes the man and all.”

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: You are in the right, Master Weathercock.

speech.speaker: CIVET.
speech.line: Soul, I think I am sure crossed, or witched with an owl.
I have haunted them: inn after inn, booth after booth, yet cannot find them. Ha, yonder they are! That’s she, I hope to God ’tis she; nay, I know ’tis she now, for she treads her shoe a little awry.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Where is this inn? We are past it, Daffodil.

speech.speaker: DAFF.
speech.line: The good sign is here, sir, but the back gate is before.

speech.speaker: CIVET.
speech.line: Save you, sir. I pray, may I borrow a piece of a word with you?

speech.speaker: DAFF.
speech.line: No pieces, sir.

speech.speaker: CIVET.
speech.line: Why, then the whole.
I pray, sir, what may yonder gentlewomen be?

speech.speaker: DAFF.
speech.line: They may be ladies, sir, if the destinies and mortality work.

speech.speaker: CIVET.
speech.line: What’s her name, sir?

speech.speaker: DAFF.
speech.line: Mistress Frances Spurcock, Sir Lancelot Spurcock’s daughter.

speech.speaker: CIVET.
speech.line: Is she a maid, sir?

speech.speaker: DAFF.
speech.line: You may ask Pluto and Dame Proserpine that:
I would be loath to be riddled, sir.

speech.speaker: CIVET.
speech.line: Is she married, I mean, sir?

speech.speaker: DAFF.
speech.line: The Fates knows not yet what shoemaker shall make her wedding shoes.

speech.speaker: CIVET.
speech.line: I pray, where inn you, sir? I would be very glad to bestow the wine of that gentlewoman.

speech.speaker: DAFF.
speech.line: At the George, sir.

speech.speaker: CIVET.
speech.line: God save you, sir.

speech.speaker: DAFF.
speech.line: I pray your name, sir?

speech.speaker: CIVET.
speech.line: My name is Master Civet, sir.

speech.speaker: DAFF.
speech.line: A sweet name; God be with you, good Master Civet.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Ah, have we spied you, stout St. George?
For all your dragon, you had best sell’s good wine —
That needs no ivy bush. Well, we’ll not sit by it,
As you do on your horse: this room shall serve.
Drawer, let me have sack for us old men:
For these girls and knaves, small wines are best.
A pint of sack, no more.

speech.speaker: DRAW.
speech.line: A quart of sack in the Three Tuns.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: A pint, draw but a pint!
Daffodil, call for wine to make yourselves drink.

speech.speaker: FRAN.
speech.line: And a cup of small beer, and a cake, good Daffodil.

stagedir.dir: Daffodil brings some drink and food.
Enter Young Flowerdale and Old Flowerdale as his servant, Christopher.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: How now! Fie, sit in the open room?
Now, good Sir Lancelot, and my kind friend, worshipful Master Weathercock,
What, at your pint? A quart, for shame!

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Nay, roister, by your leave we will away.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: Come, give’s some music, we’ll go dance.
Begone, Sir Lancelot? What, and fair day, too?

speech.speaker: LUCE.
speech.line: ’Twere foully done to dance within the fair!

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: Nay, if you say so, fairest of all fairs,
Then I’ll not dance. A pox upon my tailor,
He hath spoiled me a peach-color satin suit,

Cut upon cloth of silver. But if ever the rascal serve me such another trick, I’ll give him leave, i’faith, to put me in the calendar of fools: and you, and you, Sir Lancelot, and Master Weathercock. My goldsmith, too, on t’other side, I bespoke thee, Luce, a carcanet of gold, and thought thou shouldst ha’ had it for a fairing, and the rogue puts me in rerages for orient pearl, but thou shalt have it by Sunday night, wench.

speech.speaker: DRAW.
speech.line: Sir, here is one hath sent you a bottle of Rhenish wine brewed with rose-water.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: To me?

speech.speaker: DRAW.
speech.line: No, sir, to the knight, and desires his more acquaintance.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: To me? What’s he that proves so kind?

speech.speaker: DAFF.
speech.line: I have a trick to know his name, sir,
He hath a month’s mind here to Mistress Frances:
His name is Master Civet.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Call him in, Daffodil.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: O, I know him, sir, he is a fool, but reasonable rich. His father was one of these lease-mongers, these corn-mongers, these money-mongers, but he never had the wit to be a whore-monger.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: I promise you, sir, you are at too much charge.

speech.speaker: CIVET.
speech.line: The charge is small charge, sir. I thank God my father left me wherewithal. If it please you, sir, I have a great mind to this gentlewoman here in the way of marriage.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: I thank you, sir. Please you come to Lewisham
To my poor house, you shall be kindly welcome —
I knew your father, he was a wary husband —
To pay here, drawer!

speech.speaker: DRAW.
speech.line: All is paid, sir. This gentleman hath paid all.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: I’faith, you do us wrong,
But we shall live to make amends ere long.
Master Flowerdale, is that your man?

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: Yes, faith, a good old knave.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Nay, then, I think
You will turn wise now you take such a servant.
Come: you’ll ride with us to Lewisham? Let’s away:
’Tis scarce two hours to the end of day.

scene.scenelocation: A road near Spurcock’s house in Kent.

stagedir.dir: Enter Sir Arthur Greenshield, Oliver, Lieutenant and soldiers.

speech.speaker: ARTH.
speech.line: Lieutenant, lead your soldiers to the ships.
There let them have their coats: at their arrival,
They shall have pay. Farewell, look to your charge.

speech.speaker: LIEU.
speech.line: Ay, we are now sent away and cannot so much as speak with our friends.

speech.speaker: OLIV.
speech.line: No, man! What, ere you used ’o zutch a fashion thick you cannot take leave of your vreens?

speech.speaker: ARTH.
speech.line: Fellow, no more. Lieutenant, lead them off.

speech.speaker: LIEU.
speech.line: Well, if I have not my pay and my clothes,
I’ll venture a running away, though I hang for’t.

speech.speaker: ARTH.
speech.line: Away, sirrah, charm your tongue.

speech.speaker: OLIV.
speech.line: Bean’t you a presser, sir?

speech.speaker: ARTH.
speech.line: I am a commander, sir, under the king.

speech.speaker: OLIV.
speech.line: ’Sfoot man, an you be ne’er zutch a commander,
Should a’ spoke with my vreens before ich’ud a’ gone, zo should.

speech.speaker: ARTH.
speech.line: Content yourself, man. My authority will stretch to press so good a man as you.

speech.speaker: OLIV.
speech.line: Press me? I devy ye. Press scoundrels and thy mezels. Press me? ’Che scorns thee, i’faith. For, see’st thee, here’s a worshipful knight knows ’cham not to be pressed by thee.

stagedir.dir: Enter Sir Lancelot, Weathercock, Young Flowerdale, Old Flowerdale (in disguise), Luce, and Frances.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Sir Arthur,
Welcome to Lewisham, welcome, by my troth.
What’s the matter, man, why are you vexed?

speech.speaker: OLIV.
speech.line: Why, man, he would press me.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: O fie. Sir Arthur, press him? He is a man of reckoning.

speech.speaker: WEATH.
speech.line: Ay, that he is, Sir Arthur. He hath the nobles,
The golden ruddocks, he!

speech.speaker: ARTH.
speech.line: The fitter for the wars: and, were he not
In favor with your worships, he should see
That I have power to press so good as he.

speech.speaker: OLIV.
speech.line: ’Ch’ill stand to the trial, so ’ch’ill.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: Ay, marry, shall he — press-cloth and kersey,
White-pot and drowsen broth — tut, tut, he cannot.

speech.speaker: OLIV.
speech.line: Well, sir, though you see vlauten cloth and kersey, ’che a’ zeen zutch a kersey coat wear out the town sick a zilken jacket as thick-a one you wear.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: Well said, vlittan vlattan.

speech.speaker: OLIV.
speech.line: Ah, and well said, cocknell and Bow-bell, too: what, dost think ’cham aveard of thy zilken coat? No vear vor thee.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Nay, come, no more. Be all lovers and friends.

speech.speaker: WEATH.
speech.line: Ay, ’tis best so, good Master Oliver.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: Is your name Master Oliver, I pray you?

speech.speaker: OLIV.
speech.line: What, tit an be, tit an grieve you?

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: No, but I’d gladly know if a man might not have a foolish plot out of Master Oliver to work upon.

speech.speaker: OLIV.
speech.line: Work thy plots upon me? Stand aside! Work thy foolish plots upon me? ’Ch’ill zo use thee, thou wert never zo used since thy dame bound thy head ’ work upon me?

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: Let him come, let him come!

speech.speaker: OLIV.
speech.line: Zirrah, zirrah, if it were not vor shame, ’che would a’ given thee zutch a whister poop under the ear, ’che would a’ made thee a’ vanged another at my feet. Stand aside, let me loose, ’cham all of a vlaming fire-brand. Stand aside!

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: Well, I forbear you, for your friends’ sake.

speech.speaker: OLIV.
speech.line: A vig for all my vreens! Dost thou tell me of my vreens?

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: No more, good Master Oliver, no more,
Sir Arthur. And maiden, here in the sight
Of all your suitors, every man of worth,
I’ll tell you whom I fainest would prefer
To the hard bargain of your marriage bed:
Shall I be plain among you, gentlemen?

speech.speaker: ARTH.
speech.line: Ay, sir, ’tis best.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Then, sir, first to you:
I do confess you a most gallant knight,
A worthy soldier, and an honest man:
But honesty maintains not a French hood,
Goes very seldom in a chain of gold,
Keeps a small train of servants, hath few friends,
And for this wild oats here, young Flowerdale,
I will not judge. God can work miracles,
But he were better make a hundred new,
Than thee a thrifty and an honest one.

speech.speaker: WEATH.
speech.line: Believe me, he hath bit you there.
He hath touched you to the quick, that hath he.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: Woodcock o’ my side. Why, Master Weathercock,
You know I am honest, howsoever thriftless.

speech.speaker: WEATH.
speech.line: Now, by my troth, I know no otherwise.
O, your old mother was a dame indeed!
Heaven hath her soul, and my wife’s, too, I trust:
And your good father, honest gentleman,
He is gone a journey, as I hear, far hence.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: Ay, God be praised, he is far enough.
He is gone a pilgrimage to paradise,
And left me to cut a caper against care.
Luce, look on me that am as light as air.

speech.speaker: LUCE.
speech.line: I’faith, I like not shadows, bubbles, breath,
I hate a light o’love, as I hate death.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Girl, hold thee there. Look on this Devonshire lad:
Fat, fair, and lovely, both in purse and person.

speech.speaker: OLIV.
speech.line: Well, sir, ’cham as the lord hath made me. You know me well, y-vind. ’Che have three-score pack o’ kersey at Blackem Hall, and chief credit beside, and my fortunes may be zo good as another’s, zo it may.

speech.speaker: LUCE.
speech.line: ’Tis you I love, whatsoever others say.

speech.speaker: ARTH.
speech.line: Thanks, fairest.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: What, wouldst thou have me quarrel with him?

speech.speaker: OLD. FLOW.
speech.line: Do but say he shall hear from you.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Yet, gentlemen, howsoever I prefer
This Devonshire suitor, Iâ€™ll enforce no love.
My daughter shall have liberty to choose
Whom she likes best. In your love suit, proceed:
Not all of you, but only one must speed.

speech.speaker: WEATH.
speech.line: You have said well: indeed, right well.

speech.speaker: ART.
speech.line: Mistress, here’s one would speak with you. My fellow Daffodil hath him in the cellar already. He knows him — he met him at Croydon Fair.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: O, I remember, a little man.

speech.speaker: ART.
speech.line: Ay, a very little man.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: And yet a proper man.

speech.speaker: ART.
speech.line: A very proper, very little, man.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: His name is Monsieur Civet.

speech.speaker: ART.
speech.line: The same, sir.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Come, gentlemen. If other suitors come,
My foolish daughter will be fitted, too.
But Delia, my saint, no man dare move.

stagedir.dir: Exeunt all but Young Flowerdale, Oliver, and Old Flowerdale.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: Hark you, sir, a word.

speech.speaker: OLIV.
speech.line: What ha’an you to say to me now?

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: Ye shall hear from me, and that very shortly.

speech.speaker: OLIV.
speech.line: Is that all? Vare thee well, ’che vear thee not a vig.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: What if should come more? I am fairly dressed.

speech.speaker: OLD. FLOW.
speech.line: I do not mean that you shall meet with him,
But presently we’ll go and draw a will,
Where we’ll set down land that we never saw,
And we will have it of so large a sum,
Sir Lancelot shall entreat you take his daughter:
This being formed, give it Master Weathercock,
And make Sir Lancelot’s daughter heir of all,
And make him swear never to show the will
To anyone, until that you be dead.
This done, the foolish changing Weathercock
Will straight discourse unto Sir Lancelot
The form and tenor of your testament;
Nor stand to pause of it, be ruled by me:
What will ensue, that shall you quickly see.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: Come, let’s about it: if that a will, sweet Kit,
Can get the wench, I shall renown thy wit.

scene.scenelocation: A room in Sir Lancelot’s house.

speech.speaker: DAFF.
speech.line: Mistress, still froward?
No kind looks unto your Daffodil now, by the gods.

speech.speaker: LUCE.
speech.line: Away, you foolish knave, let my hand go.

speech.speaker: DAFF.
speech.line: There is your hand, but this shall go with me:
My heart is thine: this is my true love’s fee.

speech.speaker: LUCE.
speech.line: I’ll have your coat stripped o’er your ears for this.
You saucy rascal!

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: How now, maid, what is the news with you?

speech.speaker: LUCE.
speech.line: Your man is something saucy.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Go to, sirrah, I’ll talk with you anon.

speech.speaker: DAFF.
speech.line: Sir, I am a man to be talked withal,
I am no horse, I trow:
I know my strength, then, no more than so.

speech.speaker: WEATH.
speech.line: Ah, by the mackins,
Good Sir Lancelot, I saw him the other day
Hold up the bucklers like an Hercules.
I’faith, God ha’ mercy, lad, I like thee well.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Ay, I like him well. Go, sirrah, fetch me a cup of wine,
That ere I part with Master Weathercock,
We may drink down our farewell in French wine.

speech.speaker: WEATH.
speech.line: I thank you, sir, I thank you, friendly knight.
I’ll come and visit you, by the mouse-foot, I will:
In the meantime, take heed of cutting Flowerdale,
He is a desperate Dick, I warrant you.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: He is, he is. Fill, Daffodil, fill me some wine.—
Ha, what wears he on his arm?
My daughter Luce’s bracelet? Ay, ’tis the same.—
Ha, to you, Master Weathercock.

speech.speaker: WEATH.
speech.line: I thank you, sir. Here, Daffodil, an honest fellow and a tall thou art. Well, I’ll take my leave, good knight, and hope to have you and all your daughters, at my poor house, in good sooth I must.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Thanks, Master Weathercock. I shall be bold to trouble you, be sure.

speech.speaker: WEATH.
speech.line: And welcome; heartily farewell.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Sirrah, I saw my daughter’s wrong and, withal, her bracelet on your arm. Off with it! And with my livery, too! Have I care to see my daughter matched with men of worship, and are you grown so bold? Go, sirrah, from my house, or I’ll whip you hence.

speech.speaker: DAFF.
speech.line: I’ll not be whipped, sir, there’s your livery.
This is a serving-man’s reward! What care I?
I have means to trust to: I scorn service, ay!

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Ay, a lusty knave, but I must let him go:
Our servants must be taught what they should know.

scene.scenelocation: Another room in Sir Lancelot’s house.

speech.speaker: LUCE.
speech.line: Sir, as I am a maid, I do affect
You above any suitor that I have,
Although that soldiers scarce knows how to love.

speech.speaker: ARTH.
speech.line: I am a soldier, and a gentleman,
Knows what belongs to war, what to a lady:
What man offends me, that my sword shall right:
What woman loves me, I am her faithful knight.

speech.speaker: LUCE.
speech.line: I neither doubt your valor, nor your love,
But there be some that bears a soldier’s form,
That swears by him they never think upon,
Goes swaggering up and down from house to house
Crying, ‘God pays! And—

speech.speaker: ARTH.
speech.line: I’faith, lady, I’ll descry you such a man:
Of them there be many, which you have spoke of,
That bear the name and shape of soldiers —
Yet, God knows, very seldom saw the war —
That haunt your taverns and your ordinaries,
Your ale-houses, sometimes, for all alike
To uphold the brutish humor of their minds,
Being marked down for the bondmen of despair.
Their mirth begins in wine, but ends in blood,
Their drink is clear, but their conceits are mud.

speech.speaker: LUCE.
speech.line: Yet these are great gentlemen soldiers.

speech.speaker: ARTH.
speech.line: No, they are wretched slaves,
Whose desperate lives doth bring them timeless graves.

speech.speaker: LUCE.
speech.line: Both for yourself, and for your form of life,
If I may choose, I’ll be a soldier’s wife.

scene.scenelocation: Another room in Sir Lancelot’s house.

speech.speaker: OLIV.
speech.line: And tit trust to it, so then.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Assure yourself,
You shall be married with all speed we may:
One day shall serve for Frances and for Luce.

speech.speaker: OLIV.
speech.line: Why, ’che would vain know the time for providing wedding raiments.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Why, no more but this, first get your assurance made
Touching my daughter’s jointure. That dispatched,
We will in two days make provision.

speech.speaker: OLIV.
speech.line: Why, man, ’ch’ill have the writings made by tomorrow.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Tomorrow be it, then. Let’s meet at the King’s Head in Fish Street.

speech.speaker: OLIV.
speech.line: No, fie, man, no! Let’s meet at the Rose at Temple Bar,
That will be nearer your counselor and mine.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: At the Rose be it then, the hour nine,
He that comes last forfeits a pint of wine.

speech.speaker: OLIV.
speech.line: A pint is no payment: let it be a whole quart or nothing.

speech.speaker: ART.
speech.line: Master, here is a man would speak with Master Oliver. He comes from young Master Flowerdale.

speech.speaker: OLIV.
speech.line: Why, ’ch’ill speak with him, ’ch’ill speak with him.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Nay, son Oliver. I’ll surely see,
What young Flowerdale hath sent to you.
I pray God it be no quarrel.

speech.speaker: OLIV.
speech.line: Why, man, if he quarrel with me, ’ch’ill give him his hands full.

speech.speaker: OLD. FLOW.
speech.line: God save you, good Sir Lancelot.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Welcome, honest friend.

speech.speaker: OLD. FLOW.
speech.line: To you and yours my master wisheth health,—
But unto you, sir, this and this he sends:
There is the length, sir, of his rapier,
And in that paper shall you know his mind.

speech.speaker: OLIV.
speech.line: Here ’ch’ill meet him, my vreend, ’ch’ill meet him.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Meet him? You shall not meet the ruffian, fie.

speech.speaker: OLIV.
speech.line: An I do not meet him, ’ch’ill give you leave to call
Me cut. Where is’t, sirrah? Where is’t? Where is’t?

speech.speaker: OLD. FLOW.
speech.line: The letter shows both the time and place,
And if you be a man, then keep your word.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Sir, he shall not keep his word. He shall not meet.

speech.speaker: OLD. FLOW.
speech.line: Why, let him choose, he’ll be the better known
For a base rascal and reputed so.

speech.speaker: OLIV.
speech.line: Zirrah, zirrah, an ’twere not an old fellow, and sent after an arrant, ’ch’ud give thee something, but ’ch’ud be no money. But hold thee, for I see thou art somewhat testern, hold thee, there’s vorty shillings. Bring thy master avield, ’ch’ill give thee vorty more. Look thou bring him. ’Ch’ill maul him, tell him, ’ch’ill mar his dancing trestles. ’Ch’ill use him — he was ne’er so used since his dam bound his head. ’Ch’ill make him for capering any more, ‘che vor’ thee.

speech.speaker: OLD. FLOW.
speech.line: You seem a man stout and resolute,
And I will so report, whate’er befall.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: An’t fall out ill, assure thy master this,
I’ll make him fly the land, or use him worse.

speech.speaker: OLD. FLOW.
speech.line: My master, sir, deserves not this of you,
And that you’ll shortly find.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Thy master is an unthrift, you a knave,
And I’ll attach you first, next clap him up,
Or have him bound unto his good behavior.

speech.speaker: OLIV.
speech.line: I would you were a sprite, if you do him any harm for this. An you do, ’ch’ill ne’er zee you, nor any of yours, while ’ch’ill have eyes open. What, do you think ’ch’ill be a-baffled up and down the town for a mezel and a scoundrel? No, ‘che vor’ you.— Zirrah, ’ch’ill come. Zay no more, ’ch’ill come tell him.

speech.speaker: OLD. FLOW.
speech.line: Well, sir, my master deserves not this of you,
And that you’ll shortly find.

speech.speaker: OLIV.
speech.line: No matter. He’s an unthrift, I devy him.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Now, gentle son, let me know the place.

speech.speaker: OLIV.
speech.line: No, ‘che vor’ you.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Let me see the note.

speech.speaker: OLIV.
speech.line: Nay, ’ch’ill watch you for zutch a trick. But if ’che meet him, zo; if not, zo: ’ch’ill make him know me, or ’ch’ill know why I shall not, ’ch’ill vare the worse.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: What, will you then neglect my daughter’s love?
Venture your state, and hers, for a loose brawl?

speech.speaker: OLIV.
speech.line: Why, man, ’ch’ill not kill him. Marry, ’ch’ill veeze him, to and again. An zo, God be with you, vather. What, man, we shall met tomorrow.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Who would ha’ thought he had been so desperate?
Come forth, my honest servant Artichoke.

speech.speaker: ART.
speech.line: Now, what’s the matter? Some brawl toward, I warrant you.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Go, get me thy sword bright scoured, thy buckler mended.— O, for that knave, that villain Daffodil would have done good service.— But, to thee.

speech.speaker: ART.
speech.line: Ay, this is the tricks of all you gentlemen when you stand in need of a good fellow. ‘O, for that Daffodil! O, where is he?’ But if you be angry, an it be but for the wagging of a straw, then, ‘Out o’ doors with the knave, turn the coat over his ears.’ This is the humor of you all.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Oh, for that knave, that lusty Daffodil!

speech.speaker: ART.
speech.line: Why, there ’tis now: our year’s wages and our vails will scarce pay for broken swords and bucklers that we use in your quarrels. But I’ll not fight if Daffodil be o’ t’other side, that’s flat.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: ’Tis no such matter, man. Get weapons ready and be at London ere the break of day. Watch near the lodging of the Devonshire youth, but be unseen. And, as he goes out, as he will go out, and that very early without doubt—

speech.speaker: ART.
speech.line: What, would you have me draw upon him as he goes in the street?

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Not for a world, man,
Into the fields. For to the field he goes,
There to meet the desperate Flowerdale;
Take thou the part of Oliver my son,
For he shall be my son, and marry Luce:
Dost thou understand me, knave?

speech.speaker: ART.
speech.line: Ay, sir, I do understand you, but my young mistress might be better provided in matching with my fellow Daffodil.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: No more! Daffodil is a knave:
That Daffodil is a most notorious knave.
Master Weathercock, you come in happy time.
The desperate Flowerdale hath writ a challenge,
And who think you must answer it,
But the Devonshire man, my son Oliver?

speech.speaker: WEATH.
speech.line: Marry, I am sorry for it, good Sir Lancelot.
But, if you will be ruled by me, we’ll stay the fury.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: As how, I pray?

speech.speaker: WEATH.
speech.line: Marry, I’ll tell you, by promising young Flowerdale the red-lipped Luce.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: I’ll rather follow her unto her grave.

speech.speaker: WEATH.
speech.line: Ay, Sir Lancelot, I would have thought so, too,
But you and I have been deceived in him:
Come, read this will, or deed, or what you call it,
I know not. Come, come, your spectacles, I pray.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Nay, I thank God, I see very well.

speech.speaker: WEATH.
speech.line: Marry, God bless your eyes: mine hath been dim almost this thirty years.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Ha? What is this? What is this?

speech.speaker: WEATH.
speech.line: Nay, there is true love indeed.
He gave it to me but this very morn,
And bid me keep it unseen from anyone.
Good youth, to see how men may be deceived.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Passion of me! What a wretch am I
To hate this loving youth. He hath made me,
Together with my Luce he loves so dear,
Executors of all his wealth.

speech.speaker: WEATH.
speech.line: All, all, good man, he hath given you all.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Three ships, now in the straits, and homeward bound,
Two lordships, of two hundred pound a year:
The one in Wales, the other in Gloucestershire:
Debts and accounts are thirty thousand pound,
Plate, money, jewels, sixteen thousand more,
Two housen furnished well in Coleman Street,
Beside whatsoever his uncle leaves to him,
Being of great demesnes and wealth at Peckham.

speech.speaker: WEATH.
speech.line: How like you this, good knight? How like you this?

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: I have done him wrong, but now I’ll make amends.
The Devonshire man shall whistle for a wife.
He marry Luce? Luce shall be Flowerdale’s.

speech.speaker: WEATH.
speech.line: Why, that is friendly said.
Let’s ride to London and prevent their match,
By promising your daughter to that lovely lad.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: We’ll ride to London, or it shall not need,
We’ll cross to Deptford Strand and take a boat:
Where be these knaves? What, Artichoke, what, fop?

speech.speaker: ART.
speech.line: Here be the very knaves, but not the merry knaves.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Here, take my cloak, I’ll have a walk to Deptford.

speech.speaker: ART.
speech.line: Sir, we have been scouring of our swords and bucklers for your defense.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Defense me no defense, let your swords rust,
I’ll have no fighting: ay, let blows alone,
Bid Delia see all things be in readiness
Against the wedding: we’ll have two at once,
And that will save charges. Master Weathercock.

speech.speaker: ART.
speech.line: Well, we will do it, sir.

scene.scenelocation: The street before Sir Lancelot’s house.

speech.speaker: CIVET.
speech.line: By my truth, this is good luck; I thank God for this. In good sooth, I have even my heart’s desire. Sister Delia, now I may boldly call you so, for your father hath frank and freely given me his daughter, Franck.

speech.speaker: FRAN.
speech.line: Ay, by my troth, Tom, thou hast my good will too, for, I thank God, I longed for a husband, and would I might never stir for one whose name was Tom.

speech.speaker: DEL.
speech.line: Why, sister, now you have your wish.

speech.speaker: CIVET.
speech.line: You say very true, sister Delia, and I prithee call me nothing but Tom, and I’ll call thee sweetheart, and Franck: will it not do well, sister Delia?

speech.speaker: DEL.
speech.line: It will do very well with both of you.

speech.speaker: FRAN.
speech.line: But, Tom, must I go as I do now when I am married?

speech.speaker: CIVET.
speech.line: No, Franck. I’ll have thee go like a citizen,
In a guarded gown and a French hood.

speech.speaker: FRAN.
speech.line: By my troth, that will be excellent indeed.

speech.speaker: DEL.
speech.line: Brother, maintain your wife to your estate,
Apparel you yourself like to your father,
And let her go like to your ancient mother.
He sparing got his wealth, left it to you.
Brother, take heed of pride, some bids thrift adieu.

speech.speaker: CIVET.
speech.line: So, as my father and my mother went — that’s a jest indeed. Why, she went in a fringed gown, a single ruff, and a white cap. And my father in a mockado coat, a pair of red satin sleeves, and a canvas back.

speech.speaker: DEL.
speech.line: And yet his wealth was all as much as yours.

speech.speaker: CIVET.
speech.line: My estate, my estate, I thank God, is forty pound a year in good leases and tenements, besides twenty mark a year at Cuckold’s Haven, and that comes to us all by inheritance.

speech.speaker: DEL.
speech.line: That may indeed, ’tis very fitly plied:
I know not how it comes, but so it falls out
That those whose fathers have died wondrous rich,
And took no pleasure but to gather wealth,
Thinking of little that they leave behind:
For them they hope will be of their like mind,
But falls out contrary: forty years’ sparing
Is scarce three seven years’ spending, never caring
What will ensue, when all their coin is gone,
And all too late, then thrift is thought upon:
Oft have I heard that pride and riot kissed,
And then repentance cries, ‘For had-I-wist’.

speech.speaker: CIVET.
speech.line: You say well, sister Delia, you say well. But I mean to live within my bounds: for, look you, I have set down my rest thus far, but to maintain my wife in her French hood, and her coach, keep a couple of geldings, and a brace of greyhounds, and this is all I’ll do.

speech.speaker: DEL.
speech.line: And you’ll do this with forty pound a year?

speech.speaker: CIVET.
speech.line: Ay, and a better penny, sister.

speech.speaker: FRAN.
speech.line: Sister, you forget that at Cuckold’s Haven.

speech.speaker: CIVET.
speech.line: By my troth, well remembered, Franck.
I’ll give thee that to buy thee pins.

speech.speaker: DEL.
speech.line: Keep you the rest for points. Alas the day,
Fools shall have wealth, though all the world say nay.
Come, brother, will you in? Dinner stays for us.

speech.speaker: CIVET.
speech.line: Ay, good sister, with all my heart.

speech.speaker: FRAN.
speech.line: Ay, by my troth, Tom, for I have a good stomach.

speech.speaker: CIVET.
speech.line: And I the like, sweet Franck.— No, sister,
Do not think I’ll go beyond my bounds.

speech.speaker: DEL.
speech.line: God grant you may not!

scene.scenelocation: London. The street before Matthew Flowerdale’s house.

stagedir.dir: Enter Young Flowerdale and his Father (in disguise) with foils in their hands.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: Sirrah Kit, tarry thou there. I have spied Sir Lancelot and old Weathercock coming this way; they are hard at hand. I will by no means be spoken withal.

speech.speaker: OLD. FLOW.
speech.line: I’ll warrant you. Go, get you in!

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Now, my honest friend, thou dost belong to Master Flowerdale?

speech.speaker: OLD. FLOW.
speech.line: I do, sir.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Is he within, my good fellow?

speech.speaker: OLD. FLOW.
speech.line: No, sir, he is not within.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: I prithee, if he be within, let me speak with him.

speech.speaker: OLD. FLOW.
speech.line: Sir, to tell you true, my master is within but indeed would not be spoke withal. There be some terms that stands upon his reputation, therefore he will not admit any conference till he hath shook them off.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: I prithee, tell him his very good friend, Sir Lancelot Spurcock, entreats to speak with him.

speech.speaker: OLD. FLOW.
speech.line: By my troth, sir, if you come to take up the matter between my master and the Devonshire man, you do but beguile your hopes and lose your labor.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Honest friend, I have not any such thing to him. I come to speak with him about other matters.

speech.speaker: OLD. FLOW.
speech.line: For my master, sir, hath set down his resolution:
Either to redeem his honor, or leave his life behind him.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: My friend, I do not know any quarrel touching thy master or any other person. My business is of a different nature to him, and I prithee so tell him.

speech.speaker: OLD. FLOW.
speech.line: For howsoever the Devonshire man is,
My master’s mind is bloody, that’s a round O.
And therefore, sir, entreaty is but vain.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: I have no such thing to tell him, I tell thee once again.

speech.speaker: OLD. FLOW.
speech.line: I will then so signify to him.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Ah, sirrah, I see this matter is hotly carried,
But I’ll labor to dissuade him from it.
Good morrow. Master Flowerdale.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: Good morrow, good Sir Lancelot. Good morrow, Master Weathercock.
By my troth, gentlemen, I have been
A-reading over Nick Machiavel:
I find him good to be known, not to be followed:
A pestilent humane fellow — I have made
Certain annotations of him, such as they be.
And how is’t, Sir Lancelot? Ha? How is’t?
A mad world, men cannot live quiet in it.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Master Flowerdale, I do understand there is some jar
Between the Devonshire man and you.

speech.speaker: OLD. FLOW.
speech.line: They, sir? They are good friends as can be.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: Who, Master Oliver and I? As good friends as can be!

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: It is a kind of safety in you to deny it,
And a generous silence, which too few are endued withal:
But, sir, such a thing I hear, and I could wish it otherwise.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: No such thing, Sir Lancelot, o’ my reputation,
As I am an honest man.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Now I do believe you, then,
If you do engage your reputation, there is none.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: Nay, I do not engage my reputation there is not.
You shall not bind me to any condition of hardness:
But if there be anything between us, then there is.
If there be not, then there is not: be or be not, all is one.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: I do perceive by this that there is something between you, and I am very sorry for it.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: You may be deceived, Sir Lancelot. The Italian
Hath a pretty saying, “Questo —” I have forgot it, too.
’Tis out of my head, but in my translation,
If’t hold, thus, “Thou hast a friend, keep him, if a foe, trip him.”

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Come, I do see by this there is somewhat between you.
And before God I could wish it otherwise.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: Well, what is between us can hardly be altered.
Sir Lancelot, I am to ride forth tomorrow:
That way which I must ride, no man must deny me the sun:
I would not by any particular man
Be denied common and general passage.
If anyone saith, “Flowerdale, thou passest not this way”,
My answer is, ‘I must either on, or return’,
But “return” is not my word, I must “on”:
If I cannot then make my way, nature
Hath done the last for me, and there’s the fine.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Master Flowerdale, every man hath one tongue,
And two ears: nature in her building
Is a most curious work-master.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: That is as much to say, a man should hear more than he should speak.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: You say true and, indeed, I have heard more, than at this time I will speak.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: You say well.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Slanders are more common than truths, Master Flowerdale, but proof is the rule for both.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: You say true. What-do-you-call-him hath it there in his third canton.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: I have heard you have been wild: I have believed it.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: ’Twas fit, ’twas necessary.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: But I have seen somewhat of late in you,
That hath confirmed in me an opinion of goodness toward you.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: I’faith, sir, I am sure I never did you harm.
Some good I have done, either to you or yours,
I am sure you know not, neither is it my will you should.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Ay, your will, sir.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: Ay, my will sir. ’Sfoot, do you know aught of my will?
By God, an you do, sir, I am abused.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Go, Master Flowerdale, what I know, I know,
And know you thus much out of my knowledge,
That I truly love you. For my daughter,
She’s yours. And, if you like a marriage better
Than a brawl, all quirks of reputation
Set aside, go with me presently:
And, where you should fight a bloody battle,
You shall be married to a lovely lady.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: Nay, but Sir Lancelot—

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: If you will not embrace
My offer, yet assure yourself thus much,
I will have order to hinder your encounter.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: Nay, but hear me, Sir Lancelot—

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Nay,
Stand not you upon imputative honor:
’Tis merely unsound, unprofitable, and idle inferences.
Your business is to wed my daughter,
Therefore, give me your present word to do it.
I’ll go and provide the maid; therefore,
Give me your present resolution either now, or never.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: Will you so put me to it?

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Ay, afore God,
Either take me now, or take me never, else what
I thought should be our match, shall be our parting,
So fare you well forever.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: Stay:
Fall out what may fall, my love is above all:
I will come.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: I expect you, and so fare you well.

speech.speaker: OLD. FLOW.
speech.line: Now, sir, how shall we do for wedding apparel?

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: By the mass, that’s true. Now help, Kit,
The marriage ended, we’ll make amends for all.

speech.speaker: OLD. FLOW.
speech.line: Well, no more; prepare you for your bride:
We will not want for clothes whatsoe’er betide.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: And thou shalt see, when once I have my dower,
In mirth we’ll spend full many a merry hour.
As for this wench I not regard a pin,
It is her gold must bring my pleasures in.

speech.speaker: OLD. FLOW.
speech.line: Is’t possible he hath his second living,
Forsaking God, himself to the devil giving?
But that I knew his mother firm and chaste,
My heart would say my head she had disgraced:
Else would I swear he never was my son,
But her fair mind so foul a deed did shun.

speech.speaker: UNCLE.
speech.line: How now, brother, how do you find your son?

speech.speaker: OLD. FLOW.
speech.line: O, brother, heedless as a libertine,
Even grown a master in the school of vice,
One that doth nothing but invent deceit:
For all the day he humors up and down,
How he the next day might deceive his friend.
He thinks of nothing but the present time:
For one groat ready down, he’ll pay a shilling,
But then the lender must needs stay for it.
When I was young I had the scope of youth,
Both wild and wanton, careless and desperate,
But such mad strains as he’s possessed withal,
I thought it wonder for to dream upon.

speech.speaker: UNCLE.
speech.line: I told you so, but you would not believe it.

speech.speaker: OLD. FLOW.
speech.line: Well, I have found it, but one thing comforts me,
Brother, tomorrow he’s to be married
To beauteous Luce, Sir Lancelot Spurcock’s daughter.

speech.speaker: UNCLE.
speech.line: Is’t possible?

speech.speaker: OLD. FLOW.
speech.line: ’Tis true, and thus I mean to curb him.
This day, brother, I will you shall arrest him:
If anything will tame him, it must be that,
For he is rank in mischief, chained to a life
That will increase his shame and kill his wife.

speech.speaker: UNCLE.
speech.line: What, arrest him on his wedding day?
That were unchristian and an unhumane part.
How many couple, even for that very day,
Hath purchased seven years’ sorrow afterward?
Forbear him then today, do it tomorrow,
And this day mingle not his joy with sorrow.

speech.speaker: OLD. FLOW.
speech.line: Brother, I’ll have it done this very day,
And in the view of all as he comes from church,
Do but observe the course that he will take.
Upon my life, he will forswear the debt,
And for we’ll have the sum shall not be slight,
Say that he owes you near three thousand pound:
Good brother, let be done immediately.

speech.speaker: UNCLE.
speech.line: Well, seeing you will have it so,
Brother, I’ll do’t and straight provide the sheriff.

speech.speaker: OLD. FLOW.
speech.line: So, brother, by this means shall we perceive
What Sir Lancelot in this pinch will do:
And how his wife doth stand affected to him.
Her love will then be tried to the uttermost:
And all the rest of them. Brother, what I will do,
Shall harm him much, and much avail him, too.

speech.speaker: OLIV.
speech.line: ’Cham assured thick be the place that the scoundrel
Appointed to meet me. If a come, zo: if a come not, zo,
An ’che war avise he should make a coistrel an us,
’Ch’ud veeze him and ’che vang him in hand. ’Che would
Hoist him and give it him, to and again, zo ’ch’ud.
Who bin a-there? Sir Arthur! ’Ch’ill stay aside.

speech.speaker: ARTH.
speech.line: I have dogged the Devonshire man into the field,
For fear of any harm that should befall him:
I had an inkling of it yesternight,
That Flowerdale and he should meet this morning.
Though, of my soul, Oliver fears him not,
Yet for I’d see fair play on either side
Made me to come, to see their valors tried.
Good morrow to Master Oliver.

speech.speaker: OLIV.
speech.line: God and good morrow.

speech.speaker: ARTH.
speech.line: What, Master Oliver, are you angry?

speech.speaker: OLIV.
speech.line: Why, an it be, tit an grieven you?

speech.speaker: ARTH.
speech.line: Not me at all, sir, but I imagine,
By your being here thus armed, you stay for some
That you should fight withal.

speech.speaker: OLIV.
speech.line: Why, an he do,
’Che would not desire you to take his part.

speech.speaker: ARTH.
speech.line: No, by my troth, I think you need it not,
For he you look for I think means not to come.

speech.speaker: OLIV.
speech.line: No: an ’che war assure o’ that, ’ch’ud a’ veeze him in another place.

speech.speaker: DAFF.
speech.line: O, Sir Arthur! Master Oliver, ay me!
Your love, and yours, and mine, sweet mistress Luce,
This morn is married to young Flowerdale.

speech.speaker: ARTH.
speech.line: Married to Flowerdale! ’Tis impossible!

speech.speaker: OLIV.
speech.line: Married, man? ’Che hope thou dost but jest,
To maken a vloutin’ merriment of it.

speech.speaker: DAFF.
speech.line: O, ’tis too true. Here comes his uncle.

speech.speaker: UNCLE.
speech.line: Good morrow, Sir Arthur. Good morrow, Master Oliver.

speech.speaker: OLIV.
speech.line: God and good morn, Master Flowerdale. I pray you
Tellen us, is your scoundrel kinsman married?

speech.speaker: ARTH.
speech.line: Master Oliver, call him what you will,
But he is married to Sir Lancelot’s daughter here.

speech.speaker: UNCLE.
speech.line: Sir Arthur, unto her!

speech.speaker: OLIV.
speech.line: Ay, ha’ the old vellow zarved me thick trick?
Why, man, he was a’ promise ’ch’ill ’ch’ud a’ had her:
Is a zutch a vox? ’Ch’ill look to his water, ’che vor’ him.

speech.speaker: UNCLE.
speech.line: The music plays, they are coming from the church.
Sheriff do your office. Fellows, stand stoutly to it.

stagedir.dir: Enter all to the wedding: Flowerdale, Luce, Sir Lancelot, Master Weathercock, Old Flowerdale, Frances, Civet, Delia and Artichoke.

speech.speaker: OLIV.
speech.line: God give you joy, as the old zaid proverb is, and some zorrow among. You met us well, did you not?

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Nay, be not angry, sir. The fault is in me. I have done all the wrong, kept him from coming to the field to you, as I might sir, for I am a justice and sworn to keep the peace.

speech.speaker: WEATH.
speech.line: Ay, marry is he, sir, a very justice and sworn to keep the peace. You must not disturb the weddings.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Nay, never frown nor storm, sir. If you do,
I’ll have an order taken for you.

speech.speaker: OLIV.
speech.line: Well, well, ’ch’ill be quiet.

speech.speaker: WEATH.
speech.line: Master Flowerdale, Sir Lancelot, look you who here is? Master Flowerdale.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Master Flowerdale, welcome with all my heart.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: Uncle, this is she, i’faith.— Master Under-sheriff,
Arrest me? At whose suit? Draw, Kit!

speech.speaker: UNCLE.
speech.line: At my suit, sir.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Why, what’s the matter, Master Flowerdale?

speech.speaker: UNCLE.
speech.line: This is the matter, sir. This unthrift here
Hath cozened you, and hath had of me,
In several sums, three thousand pound.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: Why, uncle, uncle!

speech.speaker: UNCLE.
speech.line: Cousin, cousin, you have uncled me,
And if you be not stayed, you'll prove
A cozener unto all that know you.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Why, sir, suppose he be to you in debt
Ten thousand pound: his state to me appear
To be at least three thousand by the year?

speech.speaker: UNCLE.
speech.line: O sir, I was too late informèd of that plot,
How that he went about to cozen you,
And formed a will, and sent it
To your good friend there, Master Weathercock,
In which was nothing true, but brags and lies.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Ha? Hath he not such lordships, lands, and ships?

speech.speaker: UNCLE.
speech.line: Not worth a groat, not worth a halfpenny, he!

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: I pray, tell us true: be plain, young Flowerdale.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: My uncle here’s mad, and disposed to do me wrong,
But here’s my man, an honest fellow, by the lord,
And of good credit, knows all is true.

speech.speaker: OLD. FLOW.
speech.line: Not I, sir, I am too old to lie. I rather know
You forged a will, where every line you writ,
You studied where to quote your lands might lie.

speech.speaker: WEATH.
speech.line: And, I prithee, where be they, honest friend?

speech.speaker: OLD. FLOW.
speech.line: I’faith, nowhere, sir, for he hath none at all.

speech.speaker: WEATH.
speech.line: Benedicite! We are o’er-wretchèd, I believe.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: I am cozened and my hopefull’st child undone.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: You are not cozened, nor is she undone:
They slander me! By this light, they slander me!
Look you, my uncle here’s an usurer,
And would undo me, but I’ll stand in law.
Do you but bail me, you shall do no more.
You, brother Civet, and Master Weathercock, do but
Bail me and let me have my marriage money paid me,
And we’ll ride down, and there your own eyes shall see
How my poor tenants there will welcome me.
You shall but bail me, you shall do no more,
And you, greedy gnat, their bail will serve?

speech.speaker: UNCLE.
speech.line: Ay, sir, I’ll ask no better bail.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: No, sir, you shall not take my bail, nor his,
Nor my son Civet’s: I’ll not be cheated, I.
Shrieve, take your prisoner; I’ll not deal with him.
Let’s uncle make false dice with his false bones.
I will not have to do with him: mocked, gulled, and wronged.
Come, girl, though it be late, it falls out well,
Thou shalt not live with him in beggars’ hell.

speech.speaker: LUCE.
speech.line: He is my husband, and high heaven doth know,
With what unwillingness I went to church.
But you enforced me, you compelled me to it!
The holy churchman pronounced these words but now:
I must not leave my husband in distress.
Now I must comfort him, not go with you.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Comfort a cozener? On my curse, forsake him.

speech.speaker: LUCE.
speech.line: This day you caused me on your curse to take him:
Do not, I pray, my grievèd soul oppress.
God knows my heart doth bleed at his distress.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: O, Master Weathercock,
I must confess I forced her to this match,
Led with opinion his false will was true.

speech.speaker: WEATH.
speech.line: Ah, he hath over-reached me, too.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: She might have lived
Like Delia, in a happy virgin's state.

speech.speaker: DEL.
speech.line: Father, be patient, sorrow comes too late.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: And on her knees she begged and did entreat,
If she must needs taste a sad marriage life,
She craved to be Sir Arthur Greenshield’s wife.

speech.speaker: ARTH.
speech.line: You have done her and me the greater wrong.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: O, take her yet.

speech.speaker: ARTH.
speech.line: Not I.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Or Master Oliver?
Accept my child and half my wealth is yours.

speech.speaker: OLIV.
speech.line: No, sir, ’ch’ill break no laws.

speech.speaker: LUCE.
speech.line: Never fear, she will not trouble you.

speech.speaker: DEL.
speech.line: Yet, sister, in this passion,
Do not run headlong to confusion.
You may affect him, though not follow him.

speech.speaker: FRAN.
speech.line: Do, sister, hang him, let him go!

speech.speaker: WEATH.
speech.line: Do, ’faith, Mistress Luce, leave him.

speech.speaker: LUCE.
speech.line: You are three gross fools. Let me alone:
I swear I’ll live with him in all moan.

speech.speaker: OLIV.
speech.line: But an he have his legs at liberty,
’Cham aveard he will never live with you.

speech.speaker: ARTH.
speech.line: Ay, but he is now in hucksters’ handling for running away.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Hussy, you hear how you and I am wronged,
And if you will redress it, yet you may:
But, if you stand on terms to follow him,
Never come near my sight nor look on me,
Call me not father, look not for a groat,
For all thy portion I will this day give
Unto thy sister Frances.

speech.speaker: FRAN.
speech.line: How say you to that, Tom? I shall have a good deal.
Besides, I’ll be a good wife, and a good wife
Is a good thing, I can tell.

speech.speaker: CIVET.
speech.line: Peace, Franck, I would be sorry to see thy sister
Cast away, as I am a gentleman.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: What, are you yet resolved?

speech.speaker: LUCE.
speech.line: Yes, I am resolved.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Come then, away: or now or never come.

speech.speaker: LUCE.
speech.line: This way I turn. Go you unto your feast,
And I to weep that am with grief oppressed.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Forever fly my sight! Come, gentlemen,
Let’s in I’ll help you to far better wives than her.
Delia, upon my blessing, talk not to her â€”—
Base baggage, in such haste to beggary!

speech.speaker: UNCLE.
speech.line: Sheriff, take your prisoner to your charge.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: Uncle, by God you have used me very hardly,
By my troth, upon my wedding day.

stagedir.dir: Exeunt all but Young Flowerdale, his Father, Uncle, Luce, Sheriff and Officers.

speech.speaker: LUCE.
speech.line: O, Master Flowerdale, but hear me speak—
Stay but a little while, good master sheriff,
If not for him, for my sake pity him—
Good sir, stop not your ears at my complaint.
My voice grows weak, for women’s words are faint.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: Look you, uncle, she kneels to you.

speech.speaker: UNCLE.
speech.line: Fair maid — for you, I love you with my heart,
And grieve, sweet soul, thy fortune is so bad,
That thou shouldst match with such a graceless youth —
Go to thy father, think not upon him,
Whom hell hath marked to be the son of shame.

speech.speaker: LUCE.
speech.line: Impute his wildness, sir, unto his youth,
And think that now is the time he doth repent.
Alas, what good or gain can you receive
To imprison him that nothing hath to pay?
And where nought is, the king doth lose his due.
O, pity him, as God shall pity you.

speech.speaker: UNCLE.
speech.line: Lady, I know his humors all too well,
And nothing in the world can do him good,
But misery itself to chain him with.

speech.speaker: LUCE.
speech.line: Say that your debts were paid, then is he free?

speech.speaker: UNCLE.
speech.line: Ay, virgin, that being answered, I have done
But to him that is all as impossible
As I to scale the high pyramidies.
Sheriff, take your prisoner. Maiden, fare thee well.

speech.speaker: LUCE.
speech.line: O, go not yet, good Master Flowerdale:
Take my word for the debt, my word, my bond.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: Ay, by God, uncle, and my bond, too.

speech.speaker: LUCE.
speech.line: Alas, I ne’er owed nothing but I paid it,
And I can work; alas, he can do nothing:
I have some friends perhaps will pity me,
His chiefest friends do seek his misery.
All that I can or beg, get, or receive,
Shall be for you: O, do not turn away,
Methinks within a face so reverend,
So well experienced in this tottering world,
Should have some feeling of a maiden’s grief.
For my sake, his father’s and your brother’s sake,
Ay, for your soul’s sake, that doth hope for joy,
Pity my state: do not two souls destroy.

speech.speaker: UNCLE.
speech.line: Fair maid, stand up: not in regard of him,
But in pity of thy hapless choice,
I do release him. Master sheriff, I thank you:
And, officers, there is for you to drink.

stagedir.dir: He gives them a tip and they leave.

speech.line: Here, maid, take this money, there is a hundred angels,
And for I will be sure he shall not have it,
Here, Kester, take it you and use it sparingly,
But let not her have any want at all.
Dry your eyes, niece. Do not too much lament
For him, whose life hath been in riot spent:
If well he useth thee, he gets him friends.
If ill, a shameful end on him depends.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: A plague go with you for an old fornicator.
Come, Kit, the money: come, honest Kit!

speech.speaker: OLD. FLOW.
speech.line: Nay, by my faith, sir, you shall pardon me.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: And why, sir, pardon you? Give me the money,
You old rascal, or I shall make you.

speech.speaker: LUCE.
speech.line: Pray, hold your hands. Give it him, honest friend.

speech.speaker: OLD. FLOW.
speech.line: If you be so content, with all my heart.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: Content, sir? ’Sblood,
She shall be content, whether she will or no!
A rattle baby come to follow me:
Go, get you gone to the greasy chuff your father,
Bring me your dowry, or never look on me.

speech.speaker: OLD. FLOW.
speech.line: Sir, she hath forsook her father and all her friends for you.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: Hang thee, her friends, and father altogether!

speech.speaker: OLD. FLOW.
speech.line: Yet part with something to provide her lodging.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: Yes, I mean to part with her and you,
But if I part with one angel, hang me at a post.
I’ll rather throw them at a cast at dice,
As I have done a thousand of their fellows.

speech.speaker: OLD. FLOW.
speech.line: Nay, then I will be plain: degenerate boy,
Thou hadst a father would have been ashamed.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: My father was an ass, an old ass.

speech.speaker: OLD. FLOW.
speech.line: Thy father? Proud licentious villain!
What, are you at your foils? I’ll foil with you.

speech.speaker: LUCE.
speech.line: Good sir, forbear him.

speech.speaker: OLD. FLOW.
speech.line: Did not this whining woman hang on me,
I’d teach thee what it was to abuse thy father:
Go, hang, beg, starve, dice, game, that when all is gone
Thou may’st after despair and hang thyself.

speech.speaker: LUCE.
speech.line: O, do not curse him.

speech.speaker: OLD. FLOW.
speech.line: I do not curse him, and to pray for him were vain.
It grieves me that he bears his father’s name.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: Well, you old rascal, I shall meet with you.
Sirrah, get you gone, I will not strip the livery
Over your ears, because you paid for it:
But do not use my name, sirrah, do you hear?
Look you do not use my name, you were best.

speech.speaker: OLD. FLOW.
speech.line: Pay me the twenty pound, then, that I lent you,
Or give me security when I may have it.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: I’ll pay thee not a penny.
And for security, I’ll give thee none.
Minikin, look you do not follow me,
Look you do not.
If you do, beggar, I shall slit your nose.

speech.speaker: LUCE.
speech.line: Alas, what shall I do?

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: Why, turn whore, that’s a good trade:
And so, perhaps, I’ll see thee now and then.

speech.speaker: LUCE.
speech.line: Alas the day that ever I was born!

speech.speaker: OLD. FLOW.
speech.line: Sweet mistress, do not weep, I’ll stick to you.

speech.speaker: LUCE.
speech.line: Alas, my friend, I know not what to do.
My father and my friends they have despised me:
And I, a wretched maid, thus cast away,
Knows neither where to go, nor what to say.

speech.speaker: OLD. FLOW.
speech.line: It grieves me at the soul to see her tears
Thus stain the crimson roses of her cheeks—
Lady, take comfort, do not mourn in vain,
I have a little living in this town,
The which I think comes to a hundred pound,
All that and more shall be at your dispose.
I’ll straight go help you to some strange disguise,
And place you in a service in this town,
Where you shall know all, yet yourself unknown:
Come, grieve no more, where no help can be had;
Weep not for him that is worse than bad.

speech.speaker: LUCE.
speech.line: I thank you, sir.

scene.scenelocation: A room in Sir Lancelot’s house in Kent.

stagedir.dir: Enter Sir Lancelot, Master Weathercock, and to them Oliver, Civet, Frances, Delia and Sir Arthur.

speech.speaker: OLIV.
speech.line: Well, ’che a’ bin zerved many a sluttish trick,
But such a lerripoop as thick, ich was ne’er a’ zarved.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Son Civet, daughter Frances, bear with me:
You see how I am pressed down with inward grief
About that luckless girl, your sister Luce:
But ’tis fallen out with me, as with many families beside,
They are most unhappy that are most beloved.

speech.speaker: CIVET.
speech.line: Father ’tis so, ’tis even fallen out so,
But what remedy? Set hand to your heart
And let it pass. Here is your daughter, Frances, and I,
And we’ll not say we’ll bring forth as witty children,
But as pretty children, as ever she was,
Though she had the prick and praise for a pretty wench.
But father, dun is the mouse: you’ll come?

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Ay, son Civet, I’ll come.

speech.speaker: CIVET.
speech.line: And you, Master Oliver?

speech.speaker: OLIV.
speech.line: Ay, for ’che a’ vexed out this veast, ’ch’ill see if a gan
Make a better veast there.

speech.speaker: CIVET.
speech.line: And you, Sir Arthur?

speech.speaker: ARTH.
speech.line: Ay, sir, although my heart be full,
I’ll be a partner at your wedding feast.

speech.speaker: CIVET.
speech.line: And welcome all indeed, and welcome. Come, Franck, are you ready?

speech.speaker: FRAN.
speech.line: Jesu, how hasty these husbands are!
I pray, father, pray to God to bless me.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: God bless thee, and I do. God make thee wise,
Send you both joy, I wish it with wet eyes.

speech.speaker: FRAN.
speech.line: But, father, shall not my sister Delia go along with us?
She is excellent good at cookery and such things.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Yes, marry, shall she: Delia, make you ready.

speech.speaker: DEL.
speech.line: I am ready, sir. I will first go to Greenwich,
From thence to my cousin Chesterfield’s, and so to London.

speech.speaker: CIVET.
speech.line: It shall suffice, good sister Delia, it shall suffice.
But fail us not, good sister; give order to cooks and others,
For I would not have my sweet Franck
To soil her fingers.

speech.speaker: FRAN.
speech.line: No, by my troth, not I: a gentlewoman,
And a married gentlewoman, too.
To be companions to cooks and kitchen boys?
Not I, i’faith, I scorn that.

speech.speaker: CIVET.
speech.line: Why, I do not mean thou shalt, sweetheart.
Thou see’st I do not go about it. Well, farewell, to you.
God’s pity, Master Weathercock, we shall have your company, too?

speech.speaker: WEATH.
speech.line: With all my heart, for I love good cheer.

speech.speaker: CIVET.
speech.line: Well, God be with you all. Come, Franck.

speech.speaker: FRAN.
speech.line: God be with you, father, God be with you, Sir Arthur, Master Oliver, and Master Weathercock. Sister, God be with you all. God be with you father: God be with you, everyone.

speech.speaker: WEATH.
speech.line: Why, how now, Sir Arthur? All amort? Master Oliver, how now man?
Cheerily, Sir Lancelot, and merrily say,
Who can hold that will away?

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Ay, she is gone indeed, poor girl, undone,
But, when they’ll be self-willed, children must smart.

speech.speaker: ARTH.
speech.line: But, sir, that she is wronged, you are the chiefest cause.
Therefore ’tis reason you redress her wrong.

speech.speaker: WEATH.
speech.line: Indeed you must, Sir Lancelot, you must.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Must? Who can compel me, Master Weathercock?
I hope I may do what I list.

speech.speaker: WEATH.
speech.line: I grant you may: you may do what you list.

speech.speaker: OLIV.
speech.line: Nay, but an you be well avisen: it were not good,
By this vrampoldness and vrowardness, to cast away
As pretty a Dowsabel as one ’ch’ould chance to see
In a summer’s day. ’Ch’ill tell you what ’ch’all do:
’Ch’ill go spy up and down the town, and see if I
Can hear any tale or didings of her,
And take her away from thick-a mezel, vor ’cham
Assured he’ll but bring her to the spoil.
And so, vare you well, we shall meet at your son Civet’s.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: I thank you, sir, I take it very kindly.

speech.speaker: ARTH.
speech.line: To find her out I’ll spend my dearest blood,
So well I loved her, to effect her good.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: O, Master Weathercock, what hap had I to force my daughter
From Master Oliver and this good knight,
