To one that hath no goodness in his thought?

speech.speaker: WEATH.
speech.line: Ill luck, but what remedy?

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Yes, I have almost devised a remedy:
Young Flowerdale is sure a prisoner?

speech.speaker: WEATH.
speech.line: Sure? Nothing more sure.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: And yet, perhaps, his uncle hath released him.

speech.speaker: WEATH.
speech.line: It may be, very like, no doubt he hath.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Well, if he be in prison, I’ll have warrants
To ’tach my daughter till the law be tried,
For I will sue him upon cozenage.

speech.speaker: WEATH.
speech.line: Marry, may you, and overthrow him, too.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Nay, that’s not so, I may chance be scoffed,
And sentence passed with him.

speech.speaker: WEATH.
speech.line: Believe me, so he may, therefore take heed.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Well, howsoever, yet I will have warrants,
In prison or at liberty, all’s one.
You will help to serve them, Master Weathercock?

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: A plague of the devil: the devil take the dice!
The dice and the devil and his dam go together:
Of all my hundred golden angels,
I have not left me one denier:
A pox of ‘come a five’, what shall I do?
I can borrow no more of my credit,
There’s not any of my acquaintance, man nor boy,
But I have borrowed more or less of.
I would I knew where to take a good purse,
And go clear away, by this light, I’ll venture for it:
God’s lid, my sister Delia, I’ll rob her, by this hand.

speech.speaker: DEL.
speech.line: I prithee, Artichoke, go not so fast,
The weather is hot and I am something weary.

speech.speaker: ART.
speech.line: Nay, I warrant you, Mistress Delia, I’ll not tire you with leading.
We’ll go an extreme moderate pace.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: Stand! Deliver your purse!

speech.speaker: ART.
speech.line: O, lord! Thieves! Thieves!

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: Come, come, your purse, lady, your purse.

speech.speaker: DEL.
speech.line: That voice I have heard often before this time.
What, brother Flowerdale, become a thief?

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: Ay, a plague on’t, I thank your father.
But, sister, come, your money, come:
What, the world must find me; I am born to live,
’Tis not a sin to steal when none will give.

speech.speaker: DEL.
speech.line: O, God, is all grace banished from thy heart?
Think of the shame that doth attend this fact.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: Shame me no shames! Come, give me your purse!
I’ll bind you, sister, lest I fare the worse.

speech.speaker: DEL.
speech.line: No, bind me not: hold, there is all I have,
And would that money would redeem thy shame.

stagedir.dir: Enter Oliver, Sir Arthur, and Artichoke.

speech.speaker: ART.
speech.line: Thieves! Thieves! Thieves!

speech.speaker: OLIV.
speech.line: Thieves? Where, man? Why, how now, Mistress Delia?
Ha’ you a’ liked to bin a’ robbed?

speech.speaker: DEL.
speech.line: No, Master Oliver, ’tis Master Flowerdale: he did but jest with me.

speech.speaker: OLIV.
speech.line: How, Flowerdale, that scoundrel? Sirrah, you meten us well.
Vang thee that!

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: Well, sir, I’ll not meddle with you, because I have a charge.

speech.speaker: DEL.
speech.line: Here, brother Flowerdale, I’ll lend you this same money.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: I thank you, sister.

speech.speaker: OLIV.
speech.line: I wad you were y-split an you let the mezel have a penny.
But since you cannot keep it, ’ch’ill keep it myself.

speech.speaker: ARTH.
speech.line: ’Tis pity to relieve him in this sort,
Who makes a trompant life his daily sport.

speech.speaker: DEL.
speech.line: Brother, you see how all men censure you:
Farewell, and I pray God amend your life.

speech.speaker: OLIV.
speech.line: Come, ’ch’ill bring you along, and keep you safe enough,
From twenty such scoundrels as thick-a one is.
Farewell and be hanged, zirrah, as I think,
So thou wilt be shortly. Come, Sir Arthur.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: A plague go with you for a kersey rascal!
This Devonshire man, I think, is made all of pork,
His hands made only for to heave up packs,
His heart as fat and big as is his face,
As differing far from all brave gallant minds
As I to serve the hogs and drink with hinds,
As I am very near now: well, what remedy,
When money, means, and friends do grow so small,
Then farewell life, and there’s an end of all.

scene.scenelocation: Another street in London before Civet’s house.

stagedir.dir: Enter Old Flowerdate, Luce dressed like a Dutch frau, Civet and his now wife, Mistress Frances.

speech.speaker: CIVET.
speech.line: By my troth, God-a-mercy for this, good Christopher:
I thank thee for my maid. I like her very well.
How dost thou like her. Frances?

speech.speaker: FRAN.
speech.line: In good sadness, Tom, very well, excellent well,
She speaks so prettily. I pray, what’s your name?

speech.speaker: LUCE.
speech.line: My name, forsooth, be called Tannakin.

speech.speaker: FRAN.
speech.line: By my troth, a fine name. O, Tannakin, you are excellent for dressing one’s head a new fashion.

speech.speaker: LUCE.
speech.line: Me sall do everyting about da head.

speech.speaker: CIVET.
speech.line: What countrywoman is she, Kester?

speech.speaker: OLD. FLOW.
speech.line: A Dutchwoman, sir.

speech.speaker: CIVET.
speech.line: Why, then, she is outlandish, is she not?

speech.speaker: OLD. FLOW.
speech.line: Ay, sir, she is.

speech.speaker: FRAN.
speech.line: O, then thou canst tell how to help me to cheeks and ears.

speech.speaker: LUCE.
speech.line: Yes, mistress, very vell.

speech.speaker: OLD. FLOW.
speech.line: Cheeks and ears? Why, Mistress Frances, want you cheeks and ears?
Methinks you have very fair ones.

speech.speaker: FRAN.
speech.line: Thou art a fool indeed.— Tom, thou knowest what I mean.

speech.speaker: CIVET.
speech.line: Ay, ay, Kester, ’tis such as they wear o’their heads.
I prithee, Kit, have her in and show her my house.

speech.speaker: OLD. FLOW.
speech.line: I will, sir. Come, Tannakin.

speech.speaker: FRAN.
speech.line: O, Tom, you have not bussed me today, Tom.

speech.speaker: CIVET.
speech.line: No, Frances: we must not kiss afore folks. God save me. Franck.
See, yonder my sister Delia is come: welcome, good sister.

speech.speaker: FRAN.
speech.line: Welcome, good sister. How do you like the tire of my head?

speech.speaker: DEL.
speech.line: Very well, sister.

speech.speaker: CIVET.
speech.line: I am glad you’re come, sister Delia, to give order for supper: they will be here soon.

speech.speaker: ART.
speech.line: Ay, but if good luck had not served, she had not been here now.
Filching Flowerdale had like to peppered us,
But for Master Oliver, we had been robbed.

speech.speaker: DEL.
speech.line: Peace, sirrah, no more.

speech.speaker: OLD. FLOW.
speech.line: Robbed! By whom?

speech.speaker: ART.
speech.line: Marry, by none but by Flowerdale, he is turned thief.

speech.speaker: CIVET.
speech.line: By my faith, but that is not well, but God be praised
For your escape; will you draw near, sister?

speech.speaker: OLD. FLOW.
speech.line: Sirrah, come hither: would Flowerdale, he that was my master, ha’ robbed you? I prithee, tell me true.

speech.speaker: ART.
speech.line: Yes, i’faith, even that Flowerdale that was thy master.

speech.speaker: OLD. FLOW.
speech.line: Hold thee. There is a French crown, and speak no more of this.

speech.speaker: ART.
speech.line: Not I, not a word.— Now do I smell knavery:
In every purse Flowerdale takes he is half
And gives me this to keep counsel.— No, not a word, I.

speech.speaker: OLD. FLOW.
speech.line: Why, God-a-mercy!

speech.speaker: FRAN.
speech.line: Sister, look here, I have a new Dutch maid,
And she speaks so fine, it would do your heart good.

speech.speaker: CIVET.
speech.line: How do you like her, sister?

speech.speaker: DEL.
speech.line: I like your maid well.

speech.speaker: CIVET.
speech.line: Well, dear sister, will you draw near and give directions for supper?
Guests will be here presently.

speech.speaker: DEL.
speech.line: Yes, brother, lead the way, I’ll follow you.

stagedir.dir: Exeunt all but Delia and Luce.

speech.line: Hark you, Dutch frow, a word.

speech.speaker: LUCE.
speech.line: Vat is your vill wit me?

speech.speaker: DEL.
speech.line: Sister Luce, ’tis not your broken language,
Nor this same habit, can disguise your face
From I that know you: pray, tell me, what means this?

speech.speaker: LUCE.
speech.line: Sister, I see you know me, yet be secret:
This borrowed shape that I have ta’en upon me
Is but to keep myself a space unknown,
Both from my father and my nearest friends,
Until I see how time will bring to pass
The desperate course of Master Flowerdale.

speech.speaker: DEL.
speech.line: O, he is worse than bad, I prithee leave him.
And let not once thy heart to think on him.

speech.speaker: LUCE.
speech.line: Do not persuade me once to such a thought;
Imagine yet that he is worse than nought,
Yet one hour’s time may all that ill undo,
That all his former life did run into.
Therefore, kind sister, do not disclose my estate,
If e’er his heart doth turn, ’tis ne’er too late.

speech.speaker: DEL.
speech.line: Well, seeing no counsel can remove your mind,
I’ll not disclose you that art wilful blind.

speech.speaker: LUCE.
speech.line: Delia, I thank you. I now must please her eyes,
My sister Frances, neither fair nor wise.

scene.scenelocation: The street in London before Civet’s house.
scene.scenetime: In the evening a few days later.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: On goes he that knows no end of his journey.
I have passed the very utmost bounds of shifting.
I have no course now but to hang myself:
I have lived since yesterday, two o’clock, of a
Spice-cake I had at a burial, and for drink,
I got it at an alehouse among porters such as
Will bear out a man if he have no money indeed.
I mean out of their companies, for they are men
Of good carriage. Who comes here?
The two cony-catchers that won all my money of me:
I’ll try if they’ll lend me any.
What, Master Richard, how do you?
How dost thou, Rafe? By God, gentlemen, the world
Grows bare with me: will you do as much as lend
Me an angel between you both, you know
You won a hundred of me the other day?

speech.speaker: RAFE.
speech.line: How? An angel? God damn us if we lost not every penny
Within an hour after thou wert gone.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: I prithee,
Lend me so much as will pay for my supper;
I’ll pay you again, as I am a gentleman.

speech.speaker: RAFE.
speech.line: Iâ€™faith, we have not a farthing, not a mite:
I wonder at it, Master Flowerdale,
You will so carelessly undo yourself.
Why, you will lose more money in an hour
Than any honest man spends in a year:
For shame, betake you to some honest trade,
And live not thus so like a vagabond.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: A vagabond indeed! More villains you!
They gave me counsel that first cozened me:
Those devils first brought me to this I am,
And, being thus, the first that do me wrong.
Well, yet I have one friend left in store:
Not far from hence, there dwells a cockatrice,
One that I first put in a satin gown,
And not a tooth that dwell within her head,
But stands me at the least in twenty pound.
Her will I visit, now my coin is gone,
And, as I take it, here dwells the gentlewoman.
What ho, is Mistress Apricock within?

speech.speaker: RUFF.
speech.line: What saucy rascal is that which knocks so bold?
O, is it you, old spendthrift, are you here?
One that is turned cozener about the town.
My mistress saw you, and sends this word by me,
Either be packing quickly from the door,
Or you shall have such a greeting sent you straight,
As you will little like on: you had best be gone.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: Why so, this is as it should be, being poor:
Thus art thou served by a vile, painted whore.
Well, since thy damnèd crew do so abuse thee,
I’ll try of honest men, how they will use me.
Sir, I beseech you to take compassion
Of a man, one whose fortunes have been better
Than at this instant they seem to be. But,
If I might crave of you so much little portion
As would bring me to my friends, I should rest
Thankful until I had requited so great a courtesy.

speech.speaker: CIT.
speech.line: Fie, fie, young man, this course is very bad.
Too many such have we about this city.
Yet, for I have not seen you in this sort,
Nor noted you to be a common beggar.
Hold, there’s an angel to bear your charges down,
Go to your friends: do not on this depend,
Such bad beginnings oft have worser ends.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: Worser ends? Nay, if it fall out no worse
Than in old angels, I care not. Nay, now
I have had such a fortunate beginning,
I’ll not let a sixpenny purse escape me.
By the mass, here comes another.

stagedir.dir: Enter a Citizen’s Wife with Alexander, a torchbearer before her.

speech.line: God bless you, fair mistress. Now would it please you, gentlewoman, to look into the wants of a poor gentleman, a younger brother? I doubt not but God will treble restore it back again, one that never before this time demanded penny, halfpenny, nor farthing.

speech.speaker: CIT. WIFE.
speech.line: Stay, Alexander, now, by my troth, a very proper man, and ’tis great pity: hold, my friend, there’s all the money I have about me, a couple of shillings, and God bless thee.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: Now God thank you, sweet lady. If you have any screen, or garden house, where you may employ a poor gentleman as your friend, I am yours to command in all secret service.

speech.speaker: CIT. WIFE.
speech.line: I thank you, good friend. I prithee, let me see that again I gave thee: there is one of them a brass shilling. Give me them, and here is half a crown in gold.

Now, out upon thee, rascal! Secret service: what dost thou make of me? It were a good deed to have thee whipped: now I have my money again, I’ll see thee hanged before I give thee a penny. Secret service! On, good Alexander!

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: This is villainous luck: I perceive dishonesty
Will not thrive: here comes more. God forgive me,
Sir Arthur and Master Oliver! Afore God, I’ll speak to them.
God save you, Sir Arthur. God save you, Master Oliver.

speech.speaker: OLIV.
speech.line: Bin you there, zirrah?
Come, will you y-taken yourself to your tools, coistrel?

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: Nay, Master Oliver, I’ll not fight with you.
Alas, sir, you know it was not my doings,
It was only a plot to get Sir Lancelot’s daughter:
By God, I never meant you harm.

speech.speaker: OLIV.
speech.line: And whore is the gentlewoman thy wife, mezel?
Whore is she, zirrah, ha?

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: By my troth, Master Oliver, sick, very sick;
And God is my judge, I know not what means to make for her, good gentlewoman.

speech.speaker: OLIV.
speech.line: Tell me true, is she sick? Tell me true, ich ’vise thee.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: Yes, faith, I tell you true. Master Oliver, if you would do me the small kindness but to lend me forty shillings, so God help me, I will pay you so soon as my ability shall make me able, as I am a gentleman.

speech.speaker: OLIV.
speech.line: Well, thou zay’st thy wife is zick: hold, there’s vorty shillings. Give it to thy wife, look thou give it her, or I shall zo veeze thee, thou wert not so veezed this zeven year: look to it!

speech.speaker: ARTH.
speech.line: I’faith, Master Oliver, it is in vain,
To give to him that never thinks of her.

speech.speaker: OLIV.
speech.line: Well, would ’che could y-vind it.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: I tell you true, Sir Arthur, as I am a gentleman.

speech.speaker: OLIV.
speech.line: Well, fare you well, zirrah. Come, Sir Arthur.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: By the lord, this is excellent.
Five golden angels compassed in an hour:
If this trade hold, I’ll never seek a new.
Welcome, sweet gold, and beggary, adieu.

speech.speaker: UNCLE.
speech.line: See, Kester, if you can find the house.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: Who’s here? My uncle and my man Kester?
By the mass, ’tis they!
How do you, uncle? How dost thou, Kester?
By my troth, uncle, you must needs lend me
Some money: the poor gentlewoman,
My wife, so God help me, is very sick.
I was robbed of the hundred angels you gave me:
They are gone.

speech.speaker: UNCLE.
speech.line: Ay, they are gone indeed. Come, Kester, away.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: Nay, uncle. Do you hear? Good uncle.

speech.speaker: UNCLE.
speech.line: Out, hypocrite, I will not hear thee speak.
Come, leave him, Kester.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: Kester, honest Kester.

speech.speaker: OLD. FLOW.
speech.line: Sir, I have nought to say to you.—
Open the door, Tannakin: thou hadst best
Lock’t fast, for there’s a false knave without.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: You are an old lying rascal, so you are.

speech.speaker: LUCE.
speech.line: Vat is de matter? Vat be you, younker?

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: By this light, a Dutch frow, they say they are called kind:
by this light, I’ll try her.

speech.speaker: LUCE.
speech.line: Vat bin you, younker? Why do you not speak?

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: By my troth, sweetheart, a poor gentleman that would desire of you, if it stand with your liking, the bounty of your purse.

speech.speaker: LUCE.
speech.line: O, Heer God, so young an armine.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: Armine, sweet heart? I know not what you mean by that, but I am almost a beggar.

speech.speaker: LUCE.
speech.line: Are you not a married man? Vere bin your vife?
Here is all I have, take dis.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: What, gold, young frow? This is brave.

speech.speaker: OLD. FLOW.
speech.line: If he have any grace, he’ll now repent.

speech.speaker: LUCE.
speech.line: Why speak you not? Were be your vife?

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: Dead, dead, she’s dead. ’Tis she hath undone me,
Spent me all I had, and kept rascals under mine nose to brave me.

speech.speaker: LUCE.
speech.line: Did you use her vell?

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: Use her? There’s never a gentlewoman in England could be better used than I did her. I could but coach her, her diet stood me in forty pound a month, but she is dead, and in her grave my cares are buried.

speech.speaker: LUCE.
speech.line: Indeed, dat vas not schoon.

speech.speaker: OLD. FLOW.
speech.line: He is turned more devil than he was before.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: Thou dost belong to Master Civet, here, dost thou not?

speech.speaker: LUCE.
speech.line: Yes, me do.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: Why, there’s it: there’s not a handful of plate
But belongs to me. God’s my judge:
If I had but such a wench as thou art,
There’s never a man in England would make more of her
Than I would do, so she had any stock.

speech.speaker: LUCE.
speech.line: Stay, one doth call: I shall come by and by again.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: By this hand, this Dutch wench is in love with me.
Were it not admirable to make her steal
All Civet’s plate and run away?

speech.speaker: OLD. FLOW.
speech.line: ’Twere beastly. O, Master Flowerdale,
Have you no fear of God, nor conscience?
What do you mean by this vile course you take?

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: What do I mean? Why, to live, that I mean.

speech.speaker: OLD. FLOW.
speech.line: To live in this sort? Fie upon the course!
Your life doth show you are a very coward.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: A coward, I pray, in what?

speech.speaker: OLD. FLOW.
speech.line: Why, you will borrow sixpence of a boy.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: ’Snails! Is there such cowardice in that?
I dare borrow it of a man, ay,
And of the tallest man in England, if he will lend it me,
Let me borrow it how I can,
And let them come by it how they dare.
And it is well known I might ha’ rid out
A hundred times if I would, so I might.

speech.speaker: OLD. FLOW.
speech.line: It was not want of will, but cowardice.
There is none that lends to you, but know they gain,
And what is that but only stealth in you?
Delia might hang you now, did not her heart
Take pity of you, for her sister’s sake.
Go, get you hence, lest lingering here you stay,
You fall into their hands you look not for.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: I’ll tarry here till the Dutch frow comes,
If all the devils in hell were here.

stagedir.dir: Enter Sir Lancelot, Master Weathercock and Artichoke.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Where is the door? Are we not past it, Artichoke?

speech.speaker: ART.
speech.line: By th’ mass, here’s one, I’ll ask him. Do you hear, sir?
What, are you so proud? Do you hear? Which is the way
To Master Civet’s house? What, will you not speak?
O me, this is filching Flowerdale!

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: O, wonderful, is this lewd villain here?
O, you cheating rogue, you cut-purse cony-catcher!
What ditch, you villain, is my daughter’s grave?
A cozening rascal, that must make a will,
Take on him that strict habit, very that,
When he should turn to angel, a dying grace.
I’ll father-in-law you, sir, I’ll make a will!
Speak, villain, where’s my daughter?
Poisoned, I warrant you, or knocked o’ the head:
And to abuse good Master Weathercock
With his forged will — and, Master Weathercock —
To mock my grounded resolution,
Then to abuse the Devonshire gentleman:
Go, away with him to prison!

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: Wherefore to prison? Sir, I will not go.

stagedir.dir: Enter Master Civet, his wife Frances, Oliver, Sir Arthur, Father, Uncle and Delia.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: O, hereâ€™s his uncle. Welcome, gentlemen, welcome all.
Such a cozener, gentlemen, a murderer, too,
For anything I know. My daughter is missing:
Hath been looked for, cannot be found. A vild upon thee!

speech.speaker: UNCLE.
speech.line: He is my kinsman, although his life be vile,
Therefore, in God’s name, do with him what you will.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Marry, to prison.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: Wherefore to prison? Snick up, I owe you nothing.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Bring forth my daughter, then. Away with him!

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: Go, seek your daughter: what do you lay to my charge?

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Suspicion of murder. Go! Away with him!

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: Murder, you dogs? I murder your daughter?
Come, Uncle, I know you’ll bail me.

speech.speaker: UNCLE.
speech.line: Not I, were there no more than I
The jailer, thou the prisoner.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Go, away with him.

stagedir.dir: Enter Luce, disguised, as before, like a Dutch frau.

speech.speaker: LUCE.
speech.line: O’my life here, where will you ha’ de man?
Vat ha de younker done?

speech.speaker: WEATH.
speech.line: Woman, he hath killed his wife.

speech.speaker: LUCE.
speech.line: His vife? Dat is not good, dat is not schoon.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Hang not upon him, huswife, if you do, I’ll lay you by him.

speech.speaker: LUCE.
speech.line: Have me no ander way dan you have him:
He tell me dat he love me heartily.

speech.speaker: FRAN.
speech.line: Lead away my maid to prison? Why, Tom, will you suffer that?

speech.speaker: CIVET.
speech.line: No, by your leave, Father, she is no vagrant:
She is my wife’s chambermaid, and as true as the skin between any man’s brows here.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Go to, you’re both fools:
Son Civet, of my life this is a plot,
Some straggling counterfeit preferred to you,
No doubt to rob you of your plate and jewels —
I’ll have you led away to prison, trull.

speech.speaker: LUCE.
speech.line: I am no trull, neither outlandish frow,
Nor he, nor I, shall to the prison go:
Know you me now? Nay, never stand amazed.
Father, I know I have offended you,
And though that duty wills me bend my knees
To you in duty and obedience,
Yet this ways do I turn, and to him yield
My love, my duty and my humbleness.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Bastard in nature, kneel to such a slave?

speech.speaker: LUCE.
speech.line: O, Master Flowerdale, if too much grief
Have not stopped up the organs of your voice,
Then speak to her that is thy faithful wife,
Or doth contempt of me thus tie thy tongue?
Turn not away, I am no Ethiope,
No wanton Cressid, nor a changing Helen,
But rather one made wretched by thy loss.
What, turn’st thou still from me? O, then,
I guess thee woefull’st among hapless men.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: I am indeed, wife, wonder among wives!
Thy chastity and virtue hath infused
Another soul in me, red with defame,
For in my blushing cheeks is seen my shame.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Out, hypocrite! I charge thee, trust him not.

speech.speaker: LUCE.
speech.line: Not trust him? By my hopes of after-bliss,
I know no sorrow can be compared to his.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Well, since thou wert ordained to beggary,
Follow thy fortune, I defy thee, aye.

speech.speaker: OLIV.
speech.line: I would ’che were zo well y-doused as was ever white cloth in a tucking-mill, and ’che a’ not made me weep.

speech.speaker: OLD. FLOW.
speech.line: If he hath any grace, he’ll now repent.

speech.speaker: ARTH.
speech.line: It moves my heart.

speech.speaker: WEATH.
speech.line: By my troth, I must weep: I cannot choose.

speech.speaker: UNCLE.
speech.line: None but a beast would such a maid misuse.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: Content thyself. I hope to win his favor,
And to redeem my reputation lost.
And gentlemen, believe me, I beseech you,
I hope your eyes shall behold such change,
As shall deceive your expectation.

speech.speaker: OLIV.
speech.line: I would ’che were y-split now, but ’che believe him.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: How, believe him?

speech.speaker: WEATH.
speech.line: By the mackins, I do.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: What, do you think that e’er he will have grace?

speech.speaker: WEATH.
speech.line: By my faith, it will go hard.

speech.speaker: OLIV.
speech.line: Well, ’che vor’ ye, he is changed and, Master Flowerdale, in hope you been zo, hold, there’s vorty pound toward your zetting up: what, be not ashamed, vang it, man, vang it: be a good husband, loven your wife and you shall not want for vorty more, ich vor’ thee.

speech.speaker: ARTH.
speech.line: My means are little, but if you’ll follow me,
I will instruct you in my ablest power:
But to your wife I give this diamond,
And prove true diamond, fair in all your life.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: Thanks, good Sir Arthur. Master Oliver,
You being my enemy, and grown so kind,
Binds me in all endeavor to restore.

speech.speaker: OLIV.
speech.line: What? Restore me no restorings man:
I have vorty pound more for Luce. Here, vang it:
Zooth, ’ch’ill devy London else. What, do not think me
A mezel or a scoundrel to throw away my money!
’Che have a hundred pound more to purchase of any good ’spectation:
I hope your vader and your uncle here will vollow my zamples.

speech.speaker: UNCLE.
speech.line: You have guessed right of me. If he leave off this course of life, he shall be mine heir.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: But he shall never get a groat of me:
A cozener, a deceiver, one that killed
His painful father, honest gentleman,
That passed the fearful danger of the sea,
To get him living and maintain him brave.

speech.speaker: WEATH.
speech.line: What, hath he killed his father?

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Ay, sir, with conceit of his vile courses.

speech.speaker: OLD. FLOW.
speech.line: Sir, you are misinformed.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Why, thou old knave, thou told’st me so thyself.

speech.speaker: OLD. FLOW.
speech.line: I wronged him then; and, toward my master’s stock,
There’s twenty nobles for to make amends.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: No, Kester, I have troubled thee and wrong thee more,
What thou in love gives, I in love restore.

speech.speaker: FRAN.
speech.line: Ha, ha, sister, there you played bo-peep with:
Tom, what shall I give her toward household?
Sister Delia, shall I give her my fan?

speech.speaker: DEL.
speech.line: You were best ask your husband.

speech.speaker: FRAN.
speech.line: Shall I, Tom?

speech.speaker: CIVET.
speech.line: Ay, do, Franck: I’ll buy thee a new one with a longer handle.

speech.speaker: FRAN.
speech.line: A russet one, Tom.

speech.speaker: CIVET.
speech.line: Ay, with russet feathers.

speech.speaker: FRAN.
speech.line: Here, sister, there’s my fan toward household, to keep you warm.

speech.speaker: LUCE.
speech.line: I thank you, sister.

speech.speaker: WEATH.
speech.line: Why, this is well, and toward fair Luce’s stock, here’s forty shillings: and forty good shillings more I’ll give her, marry. Come, Sir Lancelot, I must have you friends.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Not I. All this is counterfeit,
He will consume it, were it a million.

speech.speaker: OLD. FLOW.
speech.line: Sir, what is your daughter’s dower worth?

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Had she been married to an honest man,
It had been better than a thousand pound.

speech.speaker: OLD. FLOW.
speech.line: Pay it him and Iâ€™ll give you my bond.
To make her jointure better worth than three.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Your bond, sir, why, what are you?

speech.speaker: OLD. FLOW.
speech.line: One whose word in London, though I say it,
Will pass there for as much as yours.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Wert not thou late that unthrift’s servingman?

speech.speaker: OLD. FLOW.
speech.line: Look on me better, now my scar is off.
Ne’er muse, man, at this metamorphosis.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Master Flowerdale!

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: My father! O, I shame to look on him.
Pardon, dear father, the follies that are past.

speech.speaker: OLD. FLOW.
speech.line: Son, son, I do, and joy at this thy change,
And applaud thy fortune in this virtuous maid,
Whom heaven hath sent to thee to save thy soul.

speech.speaker: LUCE.
speech.line: This addeth joy to joy: high heaven be praised!

speech.speaker: WEATH.
speech.line: Master Flowerdale, welcome from death, good Master Flowerdale.
’Twas said so here, ’twas said so here, good faith.

speech.speaker: OLD. FLOW.
speech.line: I caused that rumor to be spread myself,
Because I’d see the humors of my son,
Which to relate the circumstance is needless,
And, sirrah, see you run no more into that same disease,
For he that’s once cured of that malady,
Of riot, swearing, drunkenness, and pride,
And falls again into the like distress,
That fever is deadly, doth till death endure:
Such men die mad as of a calenture.

speech.speaker: FLOW.
speech.line: Heaven helping me, I’ll hate the course as hell.

speech.speaker: UNCLE.
speech.line: Say it and do it, cousin, all is well.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: Well, being in hope you’ll prove an honest man,
I take you to my favor. Brother Flowerdale,
Welcome with all my heart: I see your care
Hath brought these acts to this conclusion,
And I am glad of it: come, let’s in and feast.

speech.speaker: OLIV.
speech.line: Nay, zoft you a while, you promised to make
Sir Arthur and me amends. Here is your wisest daughter:
See which on’s sheâ€™ll have.

speech.speaker: LAN.
speech.line: O’ God’s name, you have my good will — get hers.

speech.speaker: OLIV.
speech.line: How say you then, damsel, tit on’s have?

speech.speaker: DEL.
speech.line: I, sir, am yours.

speech.speaker: OLIV.
speech.line: Why, then send for a vicar and ’ch’ill have it
Dispatched in a trice, so ’ch’ill.

speech.speaker: DEL.
speech.line: Pardon me, sir, I mean I am yours,
In love, in duty, and affection,
But not to love as wife; shall ne’er be said,
Delia was buried married, but a maid.

speech.speaker: ARTH.
speech.line: Do not condemn yourself forever,
Virtuous fair, you were born to love.

speech.speaker: OLIV.
speech.line: Why, you say true, Sir Arthur, she was y-bere to it
So well as her mother, but, I pray you, show us
Some zamples or reasons why you will not marry?

speech.speaker: DEL.
speech.line: Not that I do condemn a married life,
For ’tis no doubt a sanctimonious thing,
But for the care and crosses of a wife,
The trouble in this world that children bring,
My vow is in heaven in earth to live alone.
Husbands, howsoever good, I will have none.

speech.speaker: OLIV.
speech.line: Why then, ’ch’ill live bachelor, too.
’Che zet not a vig by a wife, if a wife zet not a vig by me. Come, shall’s go to dinner?

speech.speaker: OLD. FLOW.
speech.line: Tomorrow I crave your companies in Mark Lane:
Tonight we’ll frolic in Master Civet’s house,
And to each health drink down a full carouse.
